Y.; office, 31 Union Sq., New York, N. Y.

Author: Labor Condi- tions Abroad, 1912; various pamphlets. Member Masons, Elks, Odd Fellows, Eagles, Shriners, Lambs' Club, New York. Address, Pressmen's Home, Hawkins County, Tenn.

Name: Giuseppe Bertelli
TITLES: Author, lecturer.
ORGS: Socialist Party
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Grammar School, Florence; High School, Siena; doctor in mathematics, University of Bologna, 1892. Editor 11 Pioniere (Socialist) 1893; professor Professional School, Florence, 1895-9; editor 11 Lavoratore (Socialist), Trieste; private teacher, 1900-5. Came to United States 1906. Editor 11 Proletario (Socialist) 1906-7; La Parola del Popolo, 1908-12. Lectured on scientific and political questions and attended Socialist Party conference in almost all United States since 1922. Author: Essays of Thelemetry, Milan, 1894; Monoteismo Christianesimo, Florence, 1896; Chi Siamo Cosa Vogliamo, Florence, 1899; Karl Marx and Capital, Trieste, 1903; about 25 brochures on political, economic and sociological subjects. Socialist

Name: Warren K. Billings
TITLES: Past pres. San Francisco Shoe W. U.; was del. to San Francisco Labor Coun.; active in labor unions for yrs.; shot by scab in shoe strike, 1912; assisted Edward D. Nolan in machinists' strike, San Francisco.
ORGS: San Francisco Labor Council,San Francisco Shoe Workers Union
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Now in Folsom Penitentiary, serving life sentence for alleged complicity with Thomas J. Mooney in throwing bomb into Preparedness Day parade, San Francisco, July 22, 1916, which killed 10 persons and injured 50. Evidence presented by prosecution throughout the trials was proved to be perjured. A few days before the explosion Billings had refused a detective's offer of $5,000 to frame up Mooney as a dynamiter in the street car strike in San Francisco, July, 1916

Secretary Interchurch World Movement Commission of Inquiry 1920; responsible for Commission's Report on the Steel Strike of 1919, and Public Opinion and The Steel Strike, 1921. Member Moose, Eagles, Elks, and for 9 years president of Franz Abt Liederkranz, Millvale, Pa

Interested in amending Volstead act in favor of a 2.75% beverage. Author: article for the Pittsburgh Labor Free Press on How to Make the 18th Amendment Workable as a Temperance Measure. President local American Insurance Union 1898-9. Expert shorthand writer; owner and teacher in Bowers' Private Business School, night courses 1906-22. Garland, and other prose and poetry. President Garfield Board of Trade, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; active in civic work. Republican. Member Moose, Elks

CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Public School, Louisville, Chicago, Baltimore; Beaumont Seminary; Bachelor of Arts, Washington College, 1911; Master of Arts, Johns Hopkins, 1914; Master of Arts in history, University of Chicago, summer 1916; passed Doctor of Philosophy exam., Columbia, 1920. Organizer/Organized/Organization American Women's Emergency Committee for Lifting the Russian Blockade 1921; foreign Secretary for American Child Welfare Society 1921; 4 months in famine region of Russia, 1921; campaigned for American Friends for Russian relief 1922, for German relief 1924. Campaign Committee American Labor Party 1921; joint Amnesty Committee 1922-4; executive Committee District of Columbia branch, National Woman's Party 1923-4. Author: reports for history seminars, Johns Hopkins and Columbia University; pamphlet. Why the United States Should Recognize Russia, 1923; magazine articles. Member American Federation of Teachers, American Historical Association

Should Recognize Russia, 1923; magazine articles. Member Amer. Fed. of Teachers, Amer. Histori- cal Assn. Home, 112 E. Capitol (26)AMERlCAN LABOR WHO'S WHO St.; office, 25 1 St., Washington, D. C.

CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): High School. Southern Iowa Normal School, Bloomfield, Iowa. Was farmer; teacher. Read law in lawyer's office, 1889-92, Bloomfleld and Keosauqua, Iowa. Labor candidate for Parliament 1908, '10, '17, '21; 1st president of Canadian Labor Party 1921-4. Member Masons

Name: Hartwell Leonard Brunson
TITLES: Field secy. Workers' Educ. Bur.; asst. to pres. of Intl. Assn. of Machinists since 1921; lawyer.
ORGS: Workers' Education Bureau,International Association of Machinists,Federated Shop Crafts,Federal Board of Vocational Education,Railway Employees Department,American Federation of Labor,Masons,La Follette-Wheeler Campaign
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Country school, South Carolina and Waycross, Georgia, to 6th grade; evening High School and Benton College of Law, St. Louis. Went to work at age of 13 after death of both parents. Worked as clerk in store, in sawmill, as track laborer, and station agent's asst. until age of 16; then became machinist's apprentice; studied drafting and allied subjects in evening School; machinist in various railroad shops in United States 1895-9; in Mexico 1899-1905, engaged in railroading, mining, was general foreman, master mechanic. superintendent of Central Mejicano Railroad, then the largest in Mexico, erected mining machinery. Returned to United States 1905, employed in various railroad shops, and in construction and erection of elevators and escalators for Otis Elevator Company, until 1918; attended High School and law School nights; engaged in rehabilitation and placement of soldiers and sailors disabled in the World War, 1915-21, aiding in establishment of 146 offices for Federal Board of Vocational Educ. Member International Association of Machinists since 1895; president local 308, 1909-11; president Federated Shop Crafts 1911-5, secretary 1915-8; special representative International Association of Machinists and of Railway Employees Department, American Federation of Labor, 1915-8. Mason. Assistant director La Follette-Wheeler national campaign, 1924. Independent Progressive
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Country sen., S. C. and Waycross, Ga., to 6th grade; eve. high sch. and Benton Coll. of Law, St. Louis. Went to work at age of 13 after death of both parents. Conducted strike in Jerome, Arizona, 1917; joint strike of copper miners in Globe and Miami, Arizona, 1917, and forced settlement through President Wilson's industrial Commission headed by Secretary, of Labor William B. Wilson; conducted successful strikes in iron mines at Wharton and Oxford, New Jersey, 1913-20; after 33 years of effort on part of others, succeeded, with associates, in organizing miners of Bisbee, Arizona, and conducted 9 months strike without loss or jailing of a man; helped in Organizer/Organized/Organization steel workers and conducting strike of 1919; took charge of raising funds in New York for steel strikers, 1919, and with cooperation of unions and progressive individuals, raised $750,000. Mailed circulars to every voter in Morgan County, West Virginia, just prior to trial of President Keeney of District 7, United Mine Workers of America, charged with murder in connection with West Virginia miners' march; helped force state to discontinue case, 1922. Executive board Cooperative Leaguer. of United States America 1916-8. Active in peace movement and in agitation for Irish independence. Collected $75,000 for Irish Green Cross at meeting in Madison Sq. Garden, New York, 1919. Arrested in Philadelphia for reading Declaration of Independence at a street meeting, 1920. Candidate on Socialist Party ticket for Congress from Arizona, 1906, '8; for United States Senator from New York. 1916; for governor of New York. 1920. Speaking tours from Atlantic to Pacific. and from Mexico City to Brit. Columbia. Author: reports published in Miners' Magazine

Name: Ralph Hosea Chaplin
TITLES: Commercial artist.
ORGS: Industrial Workers of the World,General Defense Committee (Chicago)
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Grammar School to 7th grade. Went to work at age of 14. Studied in Chicago Art Institute evenings. Board director Charles H. Kerr Publishing Company, 1908-13; asst. editor Socialist and Labor Star, Huntington, West Virginia, 1912-3; editor Solidarity, Industrial Workers of the World paper, 1916. One year in Cook Company jail, awaiting trial; sentenced to 20 years under espionage act, 1918; entered Leavenworth prison Aug. 30, 1918; sentence commuted June 25, 1923. Attended trial of Centralia Industrial Workers of the World 1920; director publicity, General Defense Committee, Chicago, 1923-4. Author: When the Leaves Come Out, poems, 1917, suppressed; Bars and Shadows, prison poems, 1919; Centralia Conspiracy, 1924

Name: August Claessens
TITLES: Instr. pub. speaking, sociology, and Socialism, Rand Sch. of Social Science, New York, since 1916; lecturer for Socialist P. since 1910; for Workmen's Circle since 1923.
ORGS: Socialist Party,Workmen's Circle,Cloth Hat Cap and Millinery Workers International Union,United Auto Aircraft and Vehicle Workers,Rand School of Social Science
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Parochial and grammar son., New York; studied elocution at Cooper Union, New York; Rand School, 1908-10. Worked as newsboy; shipping clerk; grocery clerk; housepainter; street astronomer; pantomimist and elocutionist. Honorary member Cloth Hat, Cap, & Millinery Workers International Union and United Auto, Aircraft & Vehicle W. Socialist member New York. Assembly 1918-9; reelected 1920 but was refused seat with 4 other Socialist assemblymen because of membership in Socialist Party; reelected again in same year (1920) and again refused seat; reelected 1922 and seated. Candidate for Congress, New York., 1914, '24. Frequent Delegate to national and New York. Socialist Party Convention Author: Logic of Socialism, 1921; Is Socialism Inevitable?, 1922; The Trinity of Plunder, 1922. Member Workmen's Circle
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Parochial and gram, son., New York; studied elocution at Cooper Union, New York; Rand Sch., 1908-10. Auto, Aircraft & Vehicle W. Socialist member New York. CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Attended Muncie, Indiana, business college 1900-3; Toledo University at intervals. Went to work at age of 10 in glass factory. Assistant-secretary Flint Glass W. Union 1903-7; secretary 1907-9; Secretary-Treasurer 1909-16. Influential in reelection of Samuel Gompers over John Lewis as president of American Federation of Labor 1921. Active in liberty loan drives, and for Irish freedom. Author: My Travelogue, a review of a journey through 14 countries of Europe in interest of Flint Glass W. Union; Europe's Flint Glass Industry; Speeches and Addresses; many articles on various subjects. Member Knights of Columbus, Knights of St. John. Elks, Moose, Toledo Rotary Club. Democrat

Author: My Travelogue, a review of a journey through 14 countries of Europe in interest of Flint Glass W. U.; Europe's Flint Glass Industry; Speeches and Addresses; many articles on various subjects. Member K. of C., Knights of St. John. Elks, Moose, Toledo Rotary Club. Democrat.

CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Ohio public schools. Admitted to bar 1875. Elected to Illinois Legislature. 1902. ORGS: Science League of America,Workers' Party,Butte Bulletin
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Grammar, High School, business college, Philadelphia; Wellesley College, 1907-8; Bachelor of Arts, Temple University, 1911; University scholar in English, graduate School, University of Pennsylvania, 1911-2. Formerly stenographer, insurance claim adjuster, newspaper staff writer, advertising copywriter, official reporter Ford Hall Open Forum. Boston, 1913-5; clerk Ford Hall Town Meeting, 1913-5; reporter 1st Sagamore Sociological Conference, 1914. Speaker for Woman Suffrage, Massachusetts, and Pennsylvania, 1910-5; speaker for Mooney Defense, 1917. Author: many poems and articles in The Liberator, The Masses, The New York Call, Good Morning, The New Justice, The Nation, The Messenger, Poetry, The Lyric West; poems in Debs and the Poets, and several other anthologies; 1 of chapters in Democracy in the Making; play, Angels' Flight, produced in San Francisco, 1924; series of Latin translations and biographies for Haldeman-Julius. Member, Science League of A

Name: Eugene Victor Debs
TITLES: Socialist speaker and organizer; chair, natl. exec. comt. Socialist P. since 1923.
ORGS: Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen,Democratic Party,Ottowa Fire Fighters Association,Brotherhood of Railway Carmen,Switchmen's Mutual Aid Association,American Railway Union,United Mine Workers of America,Western Federation of Miners,Social Democracy of America,Social Democratic Party of America,Socialist Party,Socialist Party
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Attended School in Terre Haute until 14 years old; clerked in Father's store. Went to work in railroad paint shop for $3 a week; fireman, 16-19 years of age; with wholesale grocery firm 5 years Joined Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen 1875 and was secretary Terre Haute local; grand secretary, treasurer of Brotherhood 1880-92; editor and Manager Locomotive Firemen's Magazine, 1880-94; served as city clerk (Democratic) 2 terms of 2 years each, 1879-83; elected to Indiana Legislature on Democratic ticket 1885. In spite of other business never missed meeting of local in 10 years Organizer/Organized/Organization Brotherhood of Railway Brakemen 1884; with others Organizer/Organized/Organization Brotherhood of Railway Carmen; Organizer/Organized/Organization Switchmen's Mutual Aid Association 1885. Became acquainted with liberals of the day, including Robert G. Ingersoll and Wendell Phillips. After 16 years with Brotherhood of Railroad Firemen, resigned $4,000 salary to Organizer/Organized/Organization American Railway W. at $900 a year; president 1897. In 1st strike, Gt. Northern Railway, 1894, won 97% per cent of union demands, a monthly increase in wages of $146,000. Defeated in Pullman strike by federal court, regular troops, and 3,600 deputy marshals; indicted on charge of conspiracy to murder; charge dropped, changed to contempt of court for alleged violation of injunction; sentenced to 6 months in Woodstock jail. While in jail studied Mane and Engels; devoted rest of life to Socialism. Special Organizer/Organized/Organization for United Mine W. 1897 and for Western Federation of Miners 1897. Associate editor Appeal to Reason, editor Rip Saw. Helped organize Social Democracy of America (colonization movement), Chicago, 1897. One of founders, Chicago, 1898, and member 1st national executive board Social Democratic Party of America Assisted in organizing Socialist Party, Indianapolis. 1901. Candidate for United States President 5 times; on Social Democratic ticket 1900; Socialist Party 1904, '8, '12, '20. Convicted of violation of espionage law and sentenced to 10 years, Sept. 12, 1918; went to Atlanta prison, Apr. 13, 1919; sentence commuted by President Harding, Dec. 23, 1921; citizenship rights not restored; invalid in sanitarium most of time since release from prison. Author: many leaflets and pamphlets, including Industrial Unionism, 1905; The American Movement; Growth of Socialism; The Socialist Party or the Working Class
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Attended sch. in Terre Haute until 14 yrs. old; clerked in Father's store. Went to work in r. r. paint shop for $3 a week; fireman, 16-19 yrs. of age; with wholesale grocery firm 5 yrs. Joined Bro. of Loco. Firemen 1875 and was secy. Terre Haute local; grand secy., treas. of Bro. 1880-92; ed. and mgr. Locomotive Firemen's Magazine, 1880-94; served as city clerk (Democratic) 2 terms of 2 yrs. each, 1879-83; elected to Indiana Legls. on Democratic ticket 1885. In spite of other bus. never missed meeting of local in 10 yrs. Org. Bro. of Ry. Brakemen 1884; with others org. Bro. of Ry. Carmen; org. Switchmen's Mutual Aid Assn. 1885. Became acquainted with liberals of the day, including Robert G. Ingersoll and Wendell Phillips. After 16 yrs. with Bro. of R. R. Firemen, resigned $4,000 salary to org. Amer. Ry. W. at $900 a year; pres. 1897. In 1st strike, Gt. Northern Ry., 1894, won 97% per cent of union demands, a monthly increase in wages of $146,000. Defeated in Pullman strike by fedi. ct., regular troops, and 3,600 deputy marshals; indicted on charge of conspiracy to murder; charge dropped, changed to contempt of court for alleged violation of injunction; sentenced to 6 mos. in Woodstock jail. While in jail studied Mane and Engels; devoted rest of life to Socialism. Special org. for Un. Mine W. 1897 and for Western Fed. of Miners 1897. Asso. ed. Appeal to Reason, ed. Rip Saw. Helped organize Social Democracy of A. (colonization movt.), Chicago, 1897. One of founders, Chicago, 1898, and member 1st natl. exec. bd. Social Democratic P. of A. Assisted in organizing Socialist P., Indianapolis. 1901. Cand. for U. S. Pres. 5 times; on Social Democratic ticket 1900; Socialist P. 1904, '8, '12, '20. Convicted of violation of espionage law and sentenced to 10 yrs., Sept. 12, 1918; went to Atlanta prison, Apr. 13, 1919; sentence commuted by Pres. Harding, Dec. 23, 1921; citizenship rights not restored; invalid in sanitarium most of time since release from prison. Author: many leaflets and pamphlets, including Industrial Unionism, 1905; The American Movement; Growth of Socialism; The Socialist Party or the Working Class.

Name: Floyd Dell
TITLES: Author
ORGS: Press Writers' Union,Odd Fellows
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Primary School, Barry; grammar School, Quincy, Illinois; High School, 2 years, Davenport, Iowa; most important part of education gained in Socialist local and public library. Went to work at age of 18. Employed in candy factory, printing plant, 1905-6; newspaper reporter 1906-8, Davenport; literary critic Chicago Evening Post 1909-13; associate editor The Masses, 1914-17; The Liberator, 1918-24; contributing editor The New Review, 1915-6. Indicted, 1918, with other editors of The Masses for Socialist and editorial propaganda activities; jury disagreed, and indictment dismissed. Author: Socialism and Anarchism, a chapter in Chicago, Its History and Builders, by J. S. Currey, 1912; Women as World Builders, 1913; Were You Ever a Child? 1919, '20; Moon-Calf, 1920; The Briary-Bush, 1921; King Arthur's Socks and Other Village Plays, 1922; Janet March, 1923; Looking At Life, 1924; This Mad Ideal, 1925. Member Press Writers' U

FREE TEXT: #DEUD, Floyd. Author. Born June 28, 1887, Barry, 11l. Father a butcher. Prim, sch., Barry; gram, sch., Quincy, 11l.; high sch., 2 yrs., Davenport, Iowa; most im- portant part of education gained in Socialist loc. and pub. library. Went to work at age of 18. Em- ployed in candy factory, printing plant, 1905-6; newspaper reporter 1906-8, Davenport; literary critic Chicago Evening Post 1909-13; asso. ed. The Masses, 1914-17; The Liberator, 1918-24; contrlb. ed. The New Review, 1915-6. In- dicted, 1918, with other editors of The Masses for Socialist and edi- torial propaganda activities; jury disagreed, and indictment dis- missed. Author: "Socialism and Anarchism," a chapter in Chica- go, Its History and Builders, by J. S. Currey, 1912; Women as World Builders, 1913; Were You Ever a Child? 1919, '20; Moon- Calf, 1920; The Briary-Bush, 1921; King Arthur's Socks and Other Village Plays, 1922; Janet March, 1923; Looking At Life, 1924; This Mad Ideal, 1925. Mem- ber Press Writers' U. Address Mt. Airy Rd., Croton-on-Hudson, N. Y.

Name: Daniel Rice Donovan
TITLES: Pres. Worcester, Mass., Cent. Labor U. since 1923; secy. loc. 339, Intl. Assn. of Machinists since 1923.
ORGS: Veterans' Bureau,Socialist Party,Pocatello Building Trades Council
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): High School, N. Brookfield; Correspondence courses, Rand School of Social Science, and law, La Salle Extension University Machinist by trade. Official activities in labor and Socialist movements began after return from 10 years in California, Nevada, Wyo., and other far and middle west states, as baseball player and athletic promoter, along with work in railroad machine and automobile shop, and as ranch hand, miner, prospector, and adventurer; radical sympathies through western experiences. Leader Rand School evening classes in Springfield and Holyoke Massachusetts Candidate auditor for Massachusetts, on Socialist Party ticket, 1913. President local 24, International Association of Machinists, Springfield, 1912; fired by employer; blacklisted; business Agent, 1914; Organizer/Organized/Organization 1916-21. Chairman Labor Forward campaign, Springfield, 1915, which secured 48-hr, wk. in nearly all plants. Organized and led 1st strike of all workers at General Electric Company, Pittsfield, Massachusetts, 1916; unionization of plant successful. Delegate-at-large to Massachusetts Constitutional Convention 1917-9; Committee on social insurance Placement officer, Veterans' Bureau 1921-2. Back to machine shop 1923. Delegate 1st Massachusetts Conference Progressive Political Action 1923. Chairman Worcester County La Follette campaign, 1924. Wrote editorials for Labor Advocate, Springfield, Massachusetts, and for Labor Leader, Bridgeport, Connecticut Socialist
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): High sch., N. Brookfield; corr. courses, Rand Sch. of Social Science, and law, La Salle Extension Univ. Machinist by trade. Official activities in labor and Socialist movts. began after return from 10 yrs. in Calif., Nev., Wyo., and other far and middie west states, as baseball player and athletic promoter, along with work in r. r. machine and automobile shop, and as ranch hand, miner, prospector, and adventurer; radical sympathies through western xperlences. Leader Rand Sch. idy classes in Springfield and lyoke. Mass. Cand. auditor for Mass, on Socialist P. ticket, 1913. Pres. loc. 24, Intl. Assn. of Machinists, Springfield, 1912; fired by employer; blacklisted; bus. agt., 1914; org. 1916-21. Chair. Labor Forward campaign, Springfield, 1915, which secured 48-hr, wk. in nearly all plants. Organized and led 1st strike of all workers at Gen. Electric Co., Pittsfield, Mass., 1916; unionization of plant successful. Del.-at-large to Mass. Constitutional conv. 1917-9; comt. on social ins. Placement officer, Veterans' Bur. 1921-2. Back to machine shop 1923. Del. 1st Mass. Conf. Prog. Pol. Act. 1923. Chair. Worcester County La Follette campaign, 1924. Wrote editorials for Labor Advocate, Springfield, Mass., and for Labor Leader, Bridgeport, Conn. Socialist.

FATHER: in metal trades and govt. service.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Grammar School, Glasgow; studied economics and politics in English trade schools; Hamilton College of Law, Chicago, 1913-4. Worked as coal miner, trade union and cooperative lecturer, coal salesman. Served in various local offices of Miners' Association, Durham. England until 1910. Took active part in formation of British Labor Party 1906; in miners' 8-hour movement in northern England, 1908. Came to Union 8. 1910. Transferred to district 12, United Mine Workers of America President local 730, 1911-2; Delegate national Convention 1911-2; district wage scale Committee 1912. Helped introduce Rochdale Cooperative in Illinois and organized store in Gillespie, Illinois One of organizers of Illinois Famer-Labor Party; Delegate Convention 1920. One of organizers of Federated Press; executive board 1920; treasurer 1922-3. Speaker in shopmen's strike, 1922. Has written pamphlets on Cooperative movement in England, and trade unionism. Honorary member United Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees Member Moose
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Gram. sch., Glasgow; studied economics and politics in English trade schools; Hamilton Coll. of Law, Chicago, 1913-4. Name: Joseph James Ettor
TITLES: NONE
ORGS: Industrial Workers of the World
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Primary School, Chicago. Began work at age of 12 selling newspapers. Worked as waterboy on Railroad; apprenticed as saw flier in lumber mill; cooper 1898-1900; steel shipbuilder 1900-4; stripper boy in cigar factory 1904; sliver man in hotel 1905-6; in ship yard 1906. Organizer for Industrial Workers of the World 1906-16, member general executive board 1908-14; general Organizer/Organized/Organization and asst. general Secretary-Treasurer 1915-6. Arrested in Lawrence textile strike 1912 on charge of accessory to murder, in jail 10 months, acquitted 1912. Active in Portland, Oregon, lumber strike, 1907; McKees Rocks, Pennsylvania, steel strike, 1909; South Bethlehem steel strike 1909; Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania, coal strike 1909-10; Brooklyn shoe strike 1910-1; Paterson, New Jersey, silk strike 1913; Mesaba Range, Minnesota, iron ore strike, 1916. Dropped membership in Industrial Workers of the World 1916. Author: articles in Industrial Workers of the World and other labor papers and magazines; pamphlets, including Industrial Unionism. the Road to Freedom. 1912

Translated: Bebel's Woman and Socialism; Engel's, Origin of Private Property, The Family and The State. TITLES: Ed. English dept., Jewish Daily Forward, since 1924; contrib. ed. The New York New Leader since Dec., 1924; member New York. exec. comt. Socialist P. since 1922.

BIRTHPLACE: Antwerp, Belgium. Came to U. S. 1891.
FATHER: asso. ed. Jewish Dally Forward, New York.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Bachelor of Arts, Columbia University 1907; Master of Arts, 1908; studied at University of Wisconsin 1908. Delivered newspapers as a boy and while in college; taught Elementary night, High School; statistician for federal and state governments Associate editor The National Socialist, 1912-3; associate editor The New York Call, 1915-23; editor The Eye Opener; The Official Bulletin, The Socialist World, The New Day, The Young Socialist, published by Socialist Party, 1919-21; associate editor The New York New Leader from foundation to Dec., 1924. Director publicity, National Socialist Party 1919 -21, during presidential and amnesty campaigns. Active as Socialist speaker since 1902. Member state Committee Socialist Party of Maryland, 1910-2; Committee Kings County, New York, almost continuously since 1914; Delegate many city, state, national Conventions; several times candidate for Cong, and other offices; Socialist member New York. Assembly 1918. Delegate Convention which organized American Labor Party 1922. Member of Committee which notified Eugene V. Debs in Atlanta prison of nomination for presidency 1920. Author of Socialist pamphlets, and contributor to Socialist press in every part of world. Former member Bookkeepers', Steno. & Accountants' Union 12646; member Workmen's Circle, American Socialist Society, New Leader Publishing Co

Name: Isaac Edward Ferguson
TITLES: Lawyer; counsel for Labor Defense Coun. since 1922.

CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Bachelor of Philosophy, University of Chicago, 1910; Doctor of Jurisprudence, 1912. Active in Socialist movement 1918-9; national secretary Left Wing in Socialist Party June-Sept. 1919; executive Committee Communist Party 1919-20; editor The Communist, 1919-20. Imprisoned in New York. under criminal anarchy statute Oct. 1920; in prison 1.5 years; decision reversed by New York. Court of Appeals, July 1922

Main St., Ok- lahoma City, Okla.

TITLES: Lecturer, and natl. comt. Amer. Civil Lib. U. 1924; natl. comt . Labor Defense Coun.; bd. dir. Amer. Fund for Pub. Service since Dec. 1924.
ORGS: Workers' Defense Union
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): High School, New York. Organizer, lecturer for Industrial Workers of the World, 1906-16; Organizer/Organized/Organization Workers' Defense Union, New York, 1918-24. Arrested in New York, 1906, free speech case, dismissed; active in Spokane, Washington free speech fight, 1909; arrested, Missoula, Montana, 1909, in free speech fight of Industrial Workers of the World; Spokane, Washington, free speech fight of Industrial Workers of the World, hundreds arrested; in Philadelphia, arrested 3 times, 1911, at strike meetings of Baldwin Locomotive Works. Active in Lawrence textile strike, 1912; hotel workers strike 1912, New York; Paterson textile strike, 1913. Defense work for Ettor-Giovannitti case, 1912; Mesaba Range strike, Minnesota, 1916; Everett Industrial Workers of the World case, Spokane, Washington 1916; Joe Hill defense, 1924. Arrested Duluth, Minnesota, 1917, charged with vagrancy under law passed to stop Industrial Workers of the World and pacifist speakers; case dismissed. Indicted in Chicago Industrial Workers of the World case 1917. Arrested Philadelphia, 1920, at Sacco-Vanzetti meeting, no police permit. Active in Sacco-Vanzetti defense 1921-4. Author: Sabotage, suppressed during war

Name: William Z. Foster
TITLES: Chair. Workers' P. since 1924; secy.-treas. Trade U. Educ. Lg. since organization 1920.
ORGS: Workers' Party,Trade Union Education League,Socialist Party,Industrial Workers of the World,Brotherhood of Railway Carmen,American Federation of Labor,Syndicalist League of North America,Communist International,Red International of Labor Unions,Communist Party
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Went to work at age of 10 after attending School for 3 years Worked as a sculptor's apprentice, type founder, factory worker, steam engineer, steam fitter, railroad brakeman, railroad fireman, logger, salesman, street car motorman, longshoreman, farmer, deep water sailor, railroad car inspector. Joined Socialist Party 1900; expelled 1909 and joined Industrial Workers of the World Member Brotherhood of Railway Carmen. Arrested for participation in free speech fight, Spokane, Washington, 1909. Delegate from Industrial Workers of the World to Budapest meeting of Trade Unions Secretariat, 1910, but seat was awarded to American Federation of Labor Delegate During 13 months' study of European labor movement, became convinced that policy or dual unionism was wrong; after return to United States took part in formation Syndicalist League of North America, 1911. Helped to Organizer/Organized/Organization International Trade Union Educ. League 1916; Secretary of Committee which Organizer/Organized/Organization 200,000 packing house workers, 1917; Secretary of Committee organizing 250,000 steel workers, 1918; conducted strike of 400,000 steel workers. Went to Russia, 1921; attended Congresses Communist International and Red International of Labor Unions; joined Communist Party Candidate for United States President in 1st Communist election campaign, 1924. Author: Syndicalism; Trade Unionism the Road to Freedom; The Revolutionary Crisis, 1918-20, in Germany, England, Italy and France; The Railroaders' Next Step--Amalgamation; The Bankruptcy of the American Labor Movement; The Russian Revolution; The Great Steel Strike. Office, 1113 W. Washington Blvd., Chicago, Illinois

Author: more than 100 songs and musical compositions, poems, essays, and articles, publisher in local papers and International Stereotypers' and Electrotypers' Journal. Republican

Name: John P Frey
TITLES: Ed. Iron Molders' Journal since 1903; pres. Ohio Fed. of Labor since 1924; member of A. F. of L. comt. on educ. since 1918; secy. comt. on resolutions, A. F. of L. convs. 1908-22; member exec. bd. Work-ers' Educ. Bur. since 1921; chair. bd. dir. Natl. Bur. of Economic Research since 1923.

CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Went to work at age of 9. Received a little schooling until age of 12, when supported self and mother. Iron molder 1887-1900. President Iron Molders' local Worcester, Massachusetts, 1896-1900; treasurer New England conference board of Molders' Union, 1898-1900; vice president Massachusetts Federation of Labor, 1899; 4th vice president International Molders' Union 1900-3. Delegate American Federation of Labor since 1906; Delegate from American Federation of Labor to British Trades Union Congress 1909; to Inter-Allied Labor and Socialist conference, London, 1918; to Pan-American Federation of Labor 1921. Member of both American Federation of Labor committees sent to Europe 1918. Special lecturer on trade union economics, University of Chicago, 1908; lecturer at other colleges. President Norwood, Ohio, Board of Educ. 1918-22. Author: An American Molder in Europe, 1910; Scientific Management and Labor, 1915; The Labor Injunction, 1923; numerous pamphlets. Member Cincinnati Athletic Club and Gymnasium. Independent in politics
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Went to work at age of 9. Received a little schooling until age of 12, when supported self and mother. Iron molder 1887-1900. Pres. Iron Molders' loc. F. of L. since 1906; del. from A. F. of L. to British Trades U. Cong. 1909; to Inter-Alld. Labor and Socialist conf., London, 1918; to Pan-Amer. Fed. of Labor 1921. Member of both A. F. of L. comts. sent to Europe 1918. Special lecturer on trade union economics, Univ. of Chicago, 1908; lecturer at other colleges. Pres. Norwood, Ohio, Bd. of Educ. 1918-22. Author: An American Molder in Europe, 1910; Scientific Management and Labor, 1915; The Labor Injunc-tion, 1923; numerous pamphlets. (80)80 AMERlCAN LABOR WHO'S WHO Member Cincinnati Athl. Club and Gymnasium. Independent in politics.

Name: Esther Friedman
TITLES: Lecturer, org. for Socialist P. since 1920.

CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Public School, night High School, New York; extension courses College of City of New York 1909-10, and Teachers' College, Columbia University, 1911-2; Rand School of Social Science 1912-4. Worked as a Cigar-maker 1893-9; factory inspector since 1919. Active in commissary Department, shirt waist makers' strike, New York, 1910. Speaker during several garment workers' strikes, carmen's strike, 1914, embroidery workers' strike, Cigar-makers' strike, 1918. Lecture director Bronx Socialist Party, New York, 1911-3; education Committee 1913-5; county executive and cent. Committee 1915-7. Woman's Organizer/Organized/Organization during Suffrage campaign 1917; state executive Committee 1920. Candidate for Assembly 1916, '7; for state Senate 1918. Toured United States to secure release of political prisoners 1920. Manager Debs mass meetings, Buffalo, Youngstown, Denver, Pueblo, Cheyenne, and other cities. Member Cigar-makers' International Union of A

Cand. for Assem. 1916, '7; for state Senate 1918. Toured U. S. to secure release of political pris-oners 1920. Mgr. Debs mass meetings, Buffalo, Youngstown, Denver, Pueblo, Cheyenne, and other cities. Member Cigar-mkrs' Intl. U. of A.

Name: Harrison George
TITLES: Ed., journalist for Workers' P., since 1923.
ORGS: Socialist Party,Industrial Workers of the World,Communist Party,Red International of Labor Unions
FATHER: Ancestors settled in U. S. before Revolutionary War. Father a farmer, and stock raiser.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Attended country School Went to work in factory, Portland, Oregon when 15 years of age; postal messenger, clerk and carrier 10 years Discriminated against on account of radical beliefs; left postal service 1913; became migratory manual laborer, salesman, solicitor, shipping clerk. Joined Socialist Party 1910; expelled with left wing, 1913. Joined Industrial Workers of the World, 1914; Organizer/Organized/Organization Mesaba Range miners' strike 1916; arrested as editor of Industrial Workers of the World paper, on antiwar charges 1917; in Leaven worth prison 1918-20, when released on appeal bond. Joined United Communist Party; became editor Industrial Unionist; returned to prison Apr. 1921, and released Feb. 1923, having served full term. Delegate from Red International of Labor Unions to Industrial Workers of the World 1924. Author: The Red Dawn, 1918; The Industrial Workers of the World Trial, 1918

W. paper, on anti-war charges 1917; in Leaven worth prison 1918-20, when released on appeal bond. Joined Un. Com-munist P.; became ed. Industrial Unionist; returned to prison Apr. 1921, and released Feb. 1923, having served full term. Del. from Red Intl.of Labor Unions to I. W. W. 1924. Author: The Red Dawn, 1918; The I. W. W. Trial, 1918.

Industrial Unionist; returned to prison Apr. 1921, and released Feb. 1923, having served full term. Del. from Red Intl.of Labor Unions to I. W. W. 1924. Author: The Red Dawn, 1918; The I. W. W. Trial, 1918. Office, 1113 W. Washington Blvd., Chicago, 11l.

Name: Adolph F Germer
TITLES: Org. for Socialist P.
ORGS: Socialist Party,Knights of Pythias,United Mine Workers of America,World Miners' Congress Amsterdam,Oil Field Gas Well and Refinery Workers Union,La Follette-Wheeler Campaign,Traveling Men's Association,Automobile Club of Southern California
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Came to United States 1888. Public School, Braceville, Illinois; Lutheran Parochial School; International Correspondence School; La Salle Extension University Went to work in coal mines, Staunton, Illinois, at age of 11. Joined United Mine Workers of America 1894; local union dissolved after unsuccessful strike; rejoined 1895 in Mount Olive, Illinois; union again dissolved; rejoined 1897, when general strike was called; paid up member since then. Secretary local 728, 1906; state legislative committeeman 1907; Sub-district vice president 1907; Sub-district Secretary-Treasurer 1908-12. representative of United Mine Workers of America to World Miners' Congress Amsterdam, 1912. International Organizer/Organized/Organization 1913-4; participated in Colorado, coal strike. vice president Illinois coal miners 1915. Joined Socialist Party 1900. National secretary Socialist Party 1916-9; national Organizer/Organized/Organization 1919-20; local Organizer/Organized/Organization New York 1920-2; state secretary Massachusetts 1922. Oil worker, California 1923; member Oil Field, Gas Well & Refinery W. Union since 1923; international Organizer/Organized/Organization since 1923. Coauthor with Eugene V. Debs and Victor L. Berger of report on West Virginia coal strike for national Committee of Socialist Party, 1913. Active in La Follette-Wheeler campaign 1924. Member Knights of Pythias; Iowa State Travelling Men's Association; Automobile Club of Southern California
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Came to U. S. 1888. Pub. sch., Braceville, 11l.; Lutheran Parochial sch.; Intl. Corr. Sch.; La Salle Extension Univ. Went to work in coal mines, Staunton, 11l., at age of 11. Joined United Mine Workers of America 1894; loc. union dissolved after unsuccessful strike; rejoined 1895 in Mount Olive, 11l.; union again dissolved; rejoined 1897, when general strike was called; paid up mem-ber since then. Secy. loc. 728, 1906; state legis. committeeman 1907; sub-dist. vice-pres. 1907; sub-dist. secy.-treas. 1908-12. Rep. of United Mine Workers of America to World Miners' Cong. Amsterdam, 1912. Intl. org. 1913-4; partici-pated in Colo, coal strike. Vice-pres. 11l. coal miners 1915. Joined Socialist P. 1900. Natl. secy. Socialist P. 1916-9; natl. org. 1919-20; loc. org. New York 1920-2; state secy. Mass. 1922. Oil worker, Calif. 1923; member Oil Field, Gas Well & Refinery W. U. since 1923; intl. org. since 1923. Co-author with Eugene V. Debs and Victor L. Berger of re-port on W. Va. coal strike for natl. comt. of Socialist P., 1913. Active in La Follette-Wheeler campaign 1924. Member K. of P.; Iowa State Travelling Men's Assn.; Automobile Club of S. Calif.
PUBLICATIONS: Co-author with Eugene V. Debs and Victor L. Berger of re-port on W. Va. coal strike for national committee of Socialist Party, 1913.

Name: George H Goebel
TITLES: Org., speaker, writer, for Socialist P. for last 25 yrs.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Went halfway through grammar School Was office boy to John Wanamaker at age of 11; carpenter; traveling salesman 8 years Pioneer Organizer/Organized/Organization Socialist Party; traveled over half million miles in service of Socialist and labor movements, on everything from a mule to a dogsled, including every Railroad and most of stage routes of Union S., Canada and Brit. Columbia; spoke in practically every town of 5,000 or more inhabitants in America, and many smaller ones. some 200 miles from a railroad; in every camp or town in Alaska clear across Arctic circle; induced more people to buy Socialist books and papers than perhaps any other person. in 1 yr. securing over 13,-000 yearly subscriptions to Socialist papers; in charge of drive to purchase The People's House in New York, housing the Rand School of Social Science, and for 2 years chief of The New York Call Dependable Army. Companion speaker to Benson, Socialist Party candidate for President United States 1916, Eugene V. Debs, Jean Longuet, and others. Charter member Socialist Party; chair. 1st. New Jersey Convention; candidate for governor New Jersey; Delegate 1st and all subsequent national Conventions; national executive Committee many years, including those of war. Executive secretary Essex County, La Follette-Wheeler Club, 1924. Proponent of woman suffrage from age of 20. Author: pamphlet, Political Egypt and the Way Out. Member New York Bookkeepers, Steno. & Accountants' U

CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Came to United States 1863. Cigar maker; trade unionist since 14 years of age. Helped develop Cigar-makers'. International Union; president local 144, New York, 1876-81; 2nd vice president Cigar-makers' International Union 1887-96. 1st vice president since 1896. For short time after arrival in America was member Socialist Labor Party 1 of founders of Federation of Organized Trades & Labor Unions of United States & Canada, 1881; president 1882-6 when organization became American Federation of Labor President New York. State Workingmen's Association 1886. Delegate from American Federation of Labor to British Trades Union Congress, 1895, 1909, '18. 1st vice president National Civic Federation since 1900; advisory Committee, Committee of National Defense, 1917-9; representative American Federation of Labor at Peace Conference, Paris, 1918-9; president International Commission on Labor Legislation at Peace Conference; chair, delegates from American Federation of Labor to Convention of international Federation of Trade Unions, Amsterdam, 1919; member President's 1st Industrial Conference 1919; President's Unemployment Conference 1921; President's Advisory Disarmament Committee 1921. Author: Labor in Europe and America, 1910; American Labor and the War, 1919; Labor and the Common Welfare, 1919; Labor and the Employer, 1920; Out of Their Own Mouths, 1921; Seventy Years of Life and Labor, 1925. Member Sulgrave Institute
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Came to U. S. 1863. Cigar maker; trade union-ist since 14 yrs. of age. Helped develop Cigarmkrs'. Intl. U.; pres. loc. 144, New York, 1876-81; 2nd vice-pres. Cigarmakers' Intl. Name: Ralph Le Verne Harmon
TITLES: Secy.-treas. Farmer-Labor Fed. of Minn.; ed. its official organ Farmer-Labor Advocate since 1924; farmer.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Moved with parents to Red River Valley in pioneer wheat-raising days, and at age of 6 to western Montana moving to Flathead Valley 100 miles from railroad by stage and steamer, 1890. Educated by parents at home; worked on farms, in lumber camps, and a store, until Kalispell was founded and a School opened. graduated University of Montana, 1907; worked during vacations. Formerly insurance Agent; reporter Spokesman Review, Spokane, Wash, 1907-16; associate editor Nonpartisan Leader, Fargo, North Dakota 1916-8; editor Minnesota Leader, and Idaho Leader, 1918. Publicity director Equity Cooperative Exchange, and editor Cooperators' Herald, St. Paul, 1919-22. Secretary cent. Committee Farmer-Labor Party of Minnesota 1922-4

Formerly ins. agt.; report-er Spokesman-Review, Spokane, Wash, 1907-16; asso. ed. Non-Partisan Leader, Fargo, N. D. 1916-8; ed. Minnesota Leader, and Idaho Leader, 1918. Pub-licity dir. Equity Coop. CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): School through 4th grade. Went to work at age of 14. Formerly a printer. Member International Typographical Union since 1884. Aided in establishing The Cleveland Citizen, 1890. Member Populist Party until 1896; Socialist Labor Party until 1899; Socialist Party 1899-1919. Chair, executive Committee National Labor Party 1919; nominee of Famer-Labor Party for vice president 1920. Member Knights of Pythias, Masons, several cooperative societies

Name: William D Haywood
TITLES: Former American I.W.W. leader; lecturer for Intl. Red Aid, an organization for defense of class war prisoners, Moscow.
ORGS: Industrial Workers of the World,Socialist Labor Party,Socialist Party,Western Federation of Miners,International Red Aid,American Kuzbas Colony (Siberia)
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Went to work for a short time at age of 9 in mines; miner 1885-1901, Nevada, Utah, Idaho. Joined Western Federation of Miners 1896; executive Board, 1900-1; secretary Treasurer 1901-7.  Participated in Coeur d_Ê_Alene_Ê_s, Idaho, strike, 1899; arrested during Cripple Creek, Colorado, strike; after murder of Governor Steunenberg, Idaho, arrested with Moyer and Pettibone, 1905; held in jail 15 months, acquitted; was Socialist and Socialist Labor Party candidate for governor of Colorado while in jail. Spoke for Moyer and Pettibone after release. Helped Organizer/Organized/Organization Industrial Workers of the World 1905; secretary Treasurer 1916-18; arrested after speaking to Lawrence, Massachusetts strikers 1919; acquitted at trial; arrested in silk weavers' strike, Paterson; in jail 3 wks. refusing bail while other strikers were held in jail; sentenced to 6 months imprisonment for disorderly conduct; in Lowell, Massachusetts strike.  Arrested under espionage act; released on bail 1920; escaped to Russia. Head of American Kuzbas Colony, Siberia, 1922. Was associate editor International Socialist Review. Author: The General Strike, 1910, and other pamphlets; coauthor with F. Bohn, Industrial Socialism, 1911
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Went to work for a short time at age of 9 in mines; miner 1885-1901, Nevada, Utah, Idaho. Joined Western Fed. Of Miners 1896; exec. Bd., 1900-1; secy.-treas. 1901-7. Steunenberg, Idaho, arrested with Moyer and Pettibone, 1905; held in jail 15 mos., acquitted; was Socialist and Socialist Labor P. cand. for gov. of Colo. while in jail. Spoke for Moyer and Pettibone after release. Helped org. I.W.W. 1905; secy.-treas. 1916-18; arrested after speaking to Lawrence, Mass. strikers 1919; acquitted at trial; arrested in silk weavers' strike, Paterson; in jail 3 wks. refusing bail while other strikers were held in jail; sentenced to 6 mos. imprinsonment for disorderly conduct; in Lowell, Mass. strike.  Arrested under espionage act; released on bail 1920; escaped to Russia. Head of American Kuzbas Colony, Siberia, 1922. Was asso. ed. International Socialist Review. Author: The General Strike, 1910, and other pamphlets; co-author with F. Bohn, Industrial Socialism, 1911.

Name: Alice Henry
TITLES: Writer; lecturer.
ORGS: Charities Organization of Melbourne,Women's Trade Union League
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Private, public School, Melbourne. Taught in Melbourne; on staff of Argus and Australasian, Melbourne, and contributed extensively to other Melbourne and Sydney papers. Went to England and Belgium, 1905, as representative of Charities Organization of Melbourne. Came to United States 1906; lectured on woman suffrage and other subjects. Joined Women's Trade Union League 1907; in charge of editor and publicity work until 1910; helped found and for 5 years edited Life and Labor; became staff lecturer and Secretary of education Department of League, giving lectures on living wage, organization of women in industry, use of the vote. Director Training School, National Women's Trade Union League, Chicago, 1919-23; on leave of absence, studying workers' education in Europe, 1924. Author: The Trade Union Woman, 1915; Woman and the Labor Movement, 1923
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Private, pub. sch., Melbourne. Taught in Melbourne; on staff of Argus and Australasian, Mel-bourne, and contributed exten-sively to other Melbourne and Sydney papers. Went to Eng-land and Belgium, 1905, as rep. of Charities Organization of Melbourne. Came to U. S. 1906; lectured on woman suffrage and other subjects. Joined Women's Trade U. Lg. 1907; in charge of ed. and publicity work until 1910; helped found and for 5 yrs. edited Life and Labor; became staff lec-turer and secy, of educ. dept. of Lg., giving lectures on living wage, organization of women in industry, use of the vote. Dir. Training Sch., Natl. Women's Trade U. Lg., Chicago, 1919-23; on leave of absence, studying workers' education in Europe, 1924. FREE TEXT: #HENRY, Alice. Writer; lec- turer. Born Melbourne, Australia. Private, pub. sch., Melbourne. Taught in Melbourne; on staff of Argus and Australasian, Mel- bourne, and contributed exten- sively to other Melbourne and Sydney papers. Went to Eng- land and Belgium, 1905, as rep. of Charities Organization of Melbourne. Came to U. S. 1906; lectured on woman suffrage and other subjects. Joined Women's Trade U. Lg. 1907; in charge of ed. and publicity work until 1910; helped found and for 5 yrs. edited Life and Labor; became staff lec- turer and secy, of educ. dept. of Lg., giving lectures on living wage, organization of women in industry, use of the vote. Dir. Training Sch., Natl. Women's Trade U. Lg., Chicago, 1919-23; on leave of absence, studying workers' education in Europe, 1924. Author: The Trade Union Woman, 1915; Woman and the Labor Movement, 1923. Office, 311 S. Ashland Blvd., Chicago, 11l.

CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Grammar School, Kansas City, Missouri; left at age of 11 to go to work; Wilson's Modern Business College 3 months 1901; studied English in International Correspondence School Came to United States 1882. Member Socialist Labor Party 1897-1900; joined Socialist Party 1900; served in almost all offices; secretary Washington 1916-8; national executive Committee 1917-9; Delegate national Convention 1908, '17, '23, '4. Convicted under espionage act, 1918; sentenced to 10 years; released Dec. 24, 1921. Writer for Socialist and labor press. Member Bakers' Union since 1922; Industrial Workers of the World 1910-24; left because of its opposition to political action and other reasons

Delegate unity Convention which brought about amalgamation of Kangaroos and Debsites, Indianapolis, 1900; attended every Socialist Party Convention since then. Name: Arthur Ernest Holder
TITLES: Secy. Conf. Prog. Pol. Act. since 1923.
ORGS: Conference for Progressive Political Action,Masons,Foresters,United Workmen,Socialist Party,Iowa Bureau of Labor,Amalgamated Society of Engineers,Knights of Labor,American Labor Union,International Association of Machinists,Iowa Federation of Labor,American Federation of Labor,Federal Board for Vocational Education,People's Legislative Service
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Public School to 8th grade, Wales and England; learned much from acquaintance with trade unionists and Chartists. went to work at age of 14 as machinist's apprentice; tool maker; marine engineer; deputy Commissioner, Iowa Bureau of Labor; 1st labor inspector in Iowa, 1900-4; salesman, statistician. Admitted to Amalgamated Society of Engineers 1875; Knights of Labor 1883; secretary district assembly 212, 1886-90; Delegate Amalgamated Society of Engineers, Cardiff, Wales, 1889; American Labor Union 1893. Member International Association of Machinists since 1894. President Iowa Federation of Labor 1900-4. Associate editor Machinists' Journal 1904-6. Legislation Committee American Federation of Labor 1906-17. 1st representative of labor on Federal Board for Vocational Educ. 1917-21. Chief of legislative division, People's Legislation Service, 1921-2. Acting secretary Conference Progressive Political Action 1922-3. Helped draft 1st federal Employees workmen's compensation law 1908; 1st vocational education law 1917; 1st federal rehabilitation law for ex-service men 1918; 1st federal industrial rehabilitation law 1920; aided in writing Clayton antitrust law 1914; enactment of seamen's law 1915, and many other labor statutes. Author: articles for American Federatlonist, Machinists' Journal and other trade union publications; Railroad Strikes 1877 to 1894. Member Masons, Foresters, United Workmen. Independent in politics, usually Socialist

Name: Paul Underwood Kellogg
TITLES: Ed. Survey since 1912; ed. Survey Graphic since 1921.
ORGS: Russell Sage Foundation,American Red Cross,Charities and the Commons,Cabot Fund,Foreign Policy Association,Foreign Press Service
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Graduated from high School, Kalamazoo, 1897; special courses in political science, Columbia University, 1901-6; honorary Master of Arts, Amherst College, 1911. Folded circulars, worked at soda fountain, as a reporter, and as a Secretary after school hours; clerked in book and stationery store 1897; reporter, city editor Daily Telegraph, Kalamazoo, 1898-1901; on staff of Charities and the Commons (later The Survey) 1902. Director Pittsburgh survey, investigation of life and labor in American steel district, 1907-8 and editor of 6 vol. findings, Russell Sage Foundation; this was 1st of American community surveys, and included several original features such as 1st inductive study of work accidents in American industry; was 1st challenge to 12-hour day in steel mills. Chairman Committee on occupational standards, National Conference of Charities and Correction, 1910; Secretary of Committee to secure creation of United States Commission on Industrial Relations 1911-2; American Red Cross, France, Belgium. Italy, 1917-8. Member board of mgrs. Cabot Fund; executive Committee Foreign Policy Association; executive Committee Foreign Press Service. Coauthor, with Arthur Gleason, British Labor and the War, 1918

Marsh, John Turner, and others in publishing Freedom, London, 1898-1904; editor Modern School Magazine, and Freedom (anarchist) 1912-20. Anarchist 30 years Member Civic Club, New York

Assn. of Machin- ists, 1925; bus. agt. San Francisco loc. 1924; machinist. Born Sept. 30, 1892, Petaluma, Calif. Father a chicken rancher. Gram., high sch., San Jose; A. B., Univ. of Calif., 1914. Del. San Francisco Iron Trades Coun. 1913-8, 1923-5; active in 4 4-hr.-strike of San Francisco machinists, 1918; pres. Cent. Labor Coun., San Jose, 1918-9; led Akron, Ohio, strike of 3,000 machinists, 1919; intl. org. Intl. Assn. of Machinists, 1919-21; led 10,000 machinists in 7-mos.- strike in Cincinnati, 1920; un- successful opposition cand. for intl. pres. 1922; natl. tour in be- half of Soviet Russia, 1921-2. Del. Red Trade Unions Intl. Cong, and Communist Intl., Moscow, 1922; delivered address to gradu- ating officers of Red Army in Petrograd, on 5th anniversary of Soviet Republic. Nov. 6, 1922. Org. Machinists, San Francisco; Socialist Labor P. cand. for mayor 1923; presidential elector Socialist Labor P. of Calif. 1924. Author: articles on economics, labor movt., psychology, eco- nomic geography, science, history. Home, 2307 Greenwich St.; office. Room 208, Labor Temple, 16 & Capp St., San Francisco, Calif.

Name: Robert Marlon La Follette
TITLES: U. S. Senator from Wis. since 1905.
ORGS: Republican Party,Progressive Party
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Bachelor of Science, University of Wisconsin 1870; Doctor of Laws, 1901. Admitted to bar 1880; district attorney Dane County 1880-4. Congressman from Wisconsin 1885-91; member Ways and Means Committee, took part in framing McKinley tariff bill; Delegate Republican National Convention 1896, 1904. Governor of Wisconsin, 1901-7; resigned 1906 after election to United States Senate. Received 25 votes for presidential nomination at Republican National Convention 1908; Progressive candidate for President of United States 1924. Name: Austin Lewis
TITLES: Lawyer for labor organizations; lecturer.

CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Archbishop Holgate's School; Bachelor of Arts, University of London, 1888. Came to United States 1890. Author: The Church and Socialism. 1906; Rise of American Proletariat, 1907; Proletarian and Petit Bourgeois, 1911; Militant Proletariat, 1912; translation of Engels' Anti-Duehring, Feuerbach, and other articles and essays. No political affiliations. Member San Francisco Press Club

Conference Aug. 1924; International Labor Conference, Washington, District of Columbia, 1919. representative Canadian labor movement on National Royal Commission of Scientific & Industrial Research 1919-24. Participated in all machinists' strikes in Canada since 1908; in charge of strike operations in Eastern Canada 1908, '11, '4-7

Name: John Felix Mcnamee
TITLES: Ed. and mgr. Brotherhood of Loco-motive Firemen and Enginemen's Magazine since 1904.
ORGS: Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen,Maccabees,Citizen's League of Cleveland,Conference for Progressive Political Act
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): National School, Ireland, until age of 16. Came to United States July 1884. Worked in grocery store 3 years; factory and other employment Columbus, Ohio, 2H years Fireman, Pa, Railroad 1890-8; activities in union made it difficult to secure employment in railroad service after connection with Pennsylvania Railroad was severed, forced to do other work 1899-1901; elected to Ohio Legislature 1901. treasurer lodge 9, Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen & Enginemen 1891-7, and Delegate national Convention 1896. Organizer/Organized/Organization lodge 445 in 1897; president and Delegate to National Committee 1898-1900, '2, '4. International grand executive board 1898-1903; chair, of board 1902-3; editor and Manager 1902. Member Maccabees, Woodmen of the World, Travel Club, Citizen's League of Cleveland. Formerly Democrat; now member Conference Progressive Political Action, supported La Follette 1924
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Natl. sch., Ire-land, until age of 16. Came to U. 8. July 1884. Worked in groc-ery store 3 yrs.; factory and other employment Columbus, Ohio, 2H yrs. Fireman, Pa, R. R. 1890-8; activities in union made it diffi-cult to secure employment in r. r. service after connection with Pa. R. R. was severed, forced to do other work 1899-1901; elected to Ohio Legls. 1901. Treas. lodge 9, Bro. of Loco. Firemen & Engine-men 1891-7, and del. natl. conv. 1896. Org. lodge 445 in 1897; pres. and del. to Natl. comt. 1898-1900, '2, '4. Intl. grand exec. bd. 1898-1903; chair, of bd. 1902-3; ed. and mgr. 1902. Member Mac-cabees, Woodmen of the World, Travel Club, Citizen's Lg. of Cleve-land. Formerly Democrat; now member Conf. Prog. Pol. Act., supported La Follette 1924.

Name: Robert Minor
TITLES: Political writer, cartoonist; exec. comt. Workers' P., Chicago dist.
ORGS: Workers' Party,United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America,Odd Fellows,Socialist Party,International Workers' Defense League,Communist Party,Friends of Soviet Russia,Trade Union Education League
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Attended school 4 years Worked as sign painter, carpenter, railroad and farm laborer, journalist. Member United Brotherhood of Carpenters & Joiners of America, 1902 -5; Press Writers' Union; cent. Committee Socialist Party, St. Louis, 1910. Aided in organization of International Workers' Defense League, 1916; publicity director for Tom Mooney and codefendants in San Francisco bomb case prosecutions growing out of 1916 street car strike. Arrested in Paris, 1919, after advising French railroad unionists to strike against shipment of munitions to S. Russia. Confined in American military prison at Coblenz, Germany, for several weeks. Released after signing of treaty at Paris. Editor The Liberator from 1918 until magazine was merged in Workers' Monthly, 1924. Executive Committee Communist Party 1921-2; cent. executive Committee Workers' Party 1922-3. Indicted for attending Convention of Communist Party, Bridgeman, Michigan, 1922. Executive Committee Friends of Soviet Russia, 1923-4. Author: The Frame-Up System; Stedman's Red Raid. Member Trade Union Educ. League
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Attended sen. 4 yrs. Worked as sign painter, carpenter, r. r. and farm laborer, journalist. Member Un. Bro. of Carpenters & Joiners of A., 1902 -5; Press Writers' U.; cent. comt. Socialist P., St. Louis, 1910. Aided in organization of Intl. Workers' Defense Lg., 1916; publicity dir. for Tom Mooney and co-de-fendants in San Francisco bomb case prosecutions growing out of 1916 street car strike. Arrested in Paris, 1919, after advising French r. r. unionists to strike against shipment of munitions to S. Russia. Confined in Amer. military prison at Coblenz, Ger-many, for several weeks. Released after signing of treaty at Paris. Ed. The Liberator from 1918 until magazine was merged in Workers' Monthly, 1924. Exec. comt. Communist P. 1921-2; cent. exec. comt. Workers' P. 1922-3. Indict-ed for attending conv. of Com-munist P., Bridgeman, Mich., 1922. Exec. comt. Friends of So-viet Russia, 1923-4. Author: The Frame-Up System; Sted-man's Red Raid. Member Trade U. Educ. Lg.

Name: Thomas J Mooney
TITLES: Music teacher.
ORGS: International Molders' Union of North America,San Francisco Labor Council
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Arrested with Thomas J. Mooney, charged with complicity in throwing of bomb into Preparedness Day parade in San Francisco, California, July 22, 1916, 10 killed and 50 injured. Acquitted on 1 count on same evidence used to convict her husband and Warren K. Billings, except Oxman's perjured testimony, which was omitted. Immediately put in jail and held on other murder counts. Freed on $15,000 cash ball after 22 months in prison, Judge Dunne refusing to accept bail in Liberty Bonds. 1 of directors of Mooney defense campaign
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Arrested with Thomas J. Mooney, charged with complicity in throwing of bomb into Pre-paredness Day parade in San Francisco, Calif., July 22, 1916, 10 killed and 50 injured. Ac-quitted on 1 count on same evi-dence used to convict her hus-band and Warren K. Billings, except Oxman's perjured testi-mony, which was omitted. Imme-diately put in jail and held on other murder counts. Freed on $15,000 cash ball after 22 mos. in prison, Judge Dunne refusing to accept bail in Liberty Bonds. 1 of directors of Mooney defense cam-paign.
INDEX CATEGORY 1: Miscellaneous Groups
FREE TEXT: #MOONEY, Thomas J. Labor leader and agitator; paid-up mem- ber of Intl. Molders' U. 15 yrs.; trustee of Molders' U. 164, del San Francisco Labor Coun. 1912; Intl. Holders' conv., Milwaukee; org. Amal. Assn. of Street Car Men. In San Quentin Peniten- tiary, Calif., serving sentence of life imprisonment on charges of murder growing out of the throw- ing of a bomb into Preparedness Day parade, San Francisco, July 22, 1916. Bomb killed 10 people and injured 50. Arrested July 27, 1916, and charged with the crime with his wife, Rena, Warren K. Billings, Israel Weinberg, and Ed- ward P. Nolan. In spite of con- tradictory testimony äÛî much of which was later proved perjured, and in spite of a photograph showing a street clock, which proved that the Mooneys were on the roof of the house where they lived, a mile away from the scene of the explosionäÛîwas convicted in Feb. 1917 and sentenced in May to be hanged; later a reprieve was granted until Dec. 13, 1918. Sen- tence stayed by Pres. Wilson's in- tervention on grounds of "effects on international affairs which his execution would greatly compli- cate," changed to life imprison- ment. Earlier death sentence nul- lified because of appeal pending when date of execution arrived. Because of labor agitation, Pres. Wilson appointed a mediation comssn. to investigate; they re- ported that in trial "the Mooney case soon resolved itself into a new aspect of an old industrial feud instead of a subject demand- ing a calm search for the truth." and "evidence . , . must shake confidence in the justice of the convictions"; recommended a new trial. Supreme Ct. refused to re- view case, Mar. 1, 1918. Oxman, chief witness in securing convic- tion, was proved a perjuror; not used in Mrs. Rena Mooney's trial; she was acquitted on 1 count, as was Weinberg; both immediately arrested and held in jail without bail on other murder indictments. Billings was convicted, sentenced to life imprisonment. Nolan re- leased on ball after 9 mos. in jail, not brought to trial; proved his presence in Baltimore, Md., on date charged with constructing bomb. In Nov., 1918, J. B. Dens- more, U. S. Director-General, ap- pointed by Secy, of Labor William B. Wilson to investigate the Mooney case, submitted his re- port, in which he said that the facts he had discovered "confirm the impression made unavoidably by the weak and conflicting na- ture of the testimony in the bomb cases that practically the whole of Fickert's case against Mooney, Billings and Mrs. Mooney was made to order." On Apr. 19, 1922, Dist. Atty. M. Brady, successor to Charles M. Fickert, appealed to Gov. Stephens to pardon Mooney and Billings, saying they were convicted on false testimony.

Name: L. H. Moore
TITLES: Labor leader and agitator; paid-up mem-ber of Intl. Molders' U. 15 yrs.; trustee of Molders' U. 164, del San Francisco Labor Coun. 1912; Intl. Holders' conv., Milwaukee; org. Amal. Assn. of Street Car Men.
ORGS: Union Publishing Company,State Labor Temple Association,Workers' Party,Arkansas Farmers' Alliance,People's Party,Little Rock Central Trades Council,Arkansas Federation of Labor
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): In San Quentin Penitentiary, California, serving sentence of life imprisonment on charges of murder growing out of the throwing of a bomb into Preparedness Day parade, San Francisco, July 22, 1916. Bomb killed 10 people and injured 50. Arrested July 27, 1916, and charged with the crime with his wife, Rena, Warren K. Billings, Israel Weinberg, and Edward Party Nolan. In spite of contradictory testimony-  much of which was later proved perjured, and in spite of a photograph showing a street clock, which proved that the Mooneys were on the roof of the house where they lived, a mile away from the scene of the explosion - was convicted in Feb. 1917 and sentenced in May to be hanged; later a reprieve was granted until Dec. 13, 1918. Sentence stayed by President Wilson's intervention on grounds of effects on international affairs which his execution would greatly complicate, changed to life imprisonment. Earlier death sentence nullified because of appeal pending when date of execution arrived. Because of labor agitation, President Wilson appointed a mediation Commission to investigate; they reported that in trial the Mooney case soon resolved itself into a new aspect of an old industrial feud instead of a subject demanding a calm search for the truth. and evidence . , . must shake confidence in the justice of the convictions; recommended a new trial. Supreme Court refused to review case, Mar. 1, 1918. Oxman, chief witness in securing conviction, was proved a perjurer; not used in Mrs. Rena Mooney's trial; she was acquitted on 1 count, as was Weinberg; both immediately arrested and held in jail without bail on other murder indictments. Billings was convicted, sentenced to life imprisonment. Nolan released on ball after 9 months in jail, not brought to trial; proved his presence in Baltimore, Maryland, on date charged with constructing bomb. In Nov., 1918, J. B. Densmore, United States Director-general, appointed by Secretary, of Labor William B. Wilson to investigate the Mooney case, submitted his report, in which he said that the facts he had discovered confirm the impression made unavoidably by the weak and conflicting nature of the testimony in the bomb cases that practically the whole of Fickert's case against Mooney, Billings and Mrs. Mooney was made to order. On Apr. 19, 1922, District Attorney M. Brady, successor to Charles M. Fickert, appealed to Governor Stephens to pardon Mooney and Billings, saying they were convicted on false testimony

Name: Scott Nearing
TITLES: Economist, teacher, writer.
ORGS: Rand School of Social Science,People's Council of America,American Socialist Society,American Federation of Teachers
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Public and High School, Philadelphia; University of Pennsylvania Law School 1901-2; Bachelor of Science, University of Pennsylvania, 1905; Doctor of Philosophy, 1909; Bachelor of Oratory, Temple University, 1904. Secretary Pa, Child Labor Committee, 1905-7; instructor economics, University of Pennsylvania, 1906-14; asst. professor, 1914-5; also instructor economics Swarthmore College, 1908-13; prof, social science and dean College of Arts and Sciences, Toledo University, 1915-7; teacher and lecturer, Rand School of Social Science, New York, since 1916. Chairman People's Council of America, 1917-8. Indicted under espionage act with American Socialist Society, Apr. 1918, for publication of pamphlet The Great Madness; acquitted Feb. 1919 on all 4 counts, American Socialist Society held guilty on 2 counts. Socialist candidate for Congress, New York, 1919. Author: Economics I Sanity, 1913; Elements of Economics, 1913; Financing the Wage Karner's Family, 1914; Reducing the Cost of Living, 1914; The New Education, 1914; Income, 1915; Anthracite, 1915; Community Civics (with Jessie Field), 1915; Poverty and Riches, 1916; The Great Madness, 1918; The American Empire, 1921; The Next Step, 1922; Oil and the Germs of War, 1924. Contributor to economic and other journals and magazines. Member of American Federation of Teachers

Name: Walter Nelles
TITLES: Lawyer, counsel Amer. Civil Lib. U. since 1917; counsel Amer. Fund for Pub. Service since 1922.
ORGS: League for Industrial Democracy,American Civil Liberties Union
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Philips-Exeter Academy; Bachelor of Arts, Harvard, 1905; Master of Arts, 1908; Bachelor of Laws, 1911. Instructor University of Wisconsin 1905-7, Lowell Institute and Radcliffe College 1907-11. Of counsel for defendants in prosecutions under espionage act, 1917-9, including cases of Scott Nearing, American Socialist Society, Max Eastman and others; for conscientious objectors in court martial proceedings in same period, including the case of Ernest Gellert; for New York. Socialist assemblymen in the legislative expulsion proceedings, 1920; in deportation cases, including those of Alexis Georgian, Roberto Ella, Gaspare CanNONE, and Mahler v. Eby, 1918-24; in so-called criminal anarchy and sedition prosecutions, including those of Tihon Sinchuk (Supreme Court of Errors of Connecticut 1922) and Benjamin Gitlow (New York courts, 1919-22, and United States Supreme Court, 1922-4). Author: Espionage Act Cases, 1918; In the Wake of the Espionage Act, The Nation, 1920, and other articles and book reviews; editor Law and Freedom Bulletins for American Civil Liberties Union, covering court decisions affecting civil liberties and rights of labor organizations. Member League for Industrial Democracy

Name: Walter Morrow Nelson
TITLES: Lawyer.
ORGS: United Mine Workers of America,American Civil Liberties Union,Detroit Bar Association,Michigan Bar Association,University of Michigan Club,Ethical Society (Detroit),Masons
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Primary School, Columbus, Ohio; grammar and High School, Albia, Iowa; Bachelor of Laws, University of Michigan, 1912. Formerly a coal miner and member local 1799, United Mine Workers of America, 1908-9. Contributed services to conscientious objectors, 1917; to American Civil Liberties Union since 1913; handled scores of cases for persons arrested during Palmer raids, 1919-20; representative Nicolai Mansevich and others attempted to be deported for opinions; repeatedly argued Michigan Federation of Labor demands for improvement of state workmen's compensation act; representative Detroit Building Trades Council in injunction case in federal court, strike of 1920; representative Edwin Cornish, editor of a labor paper sentenced for contempt in a federal court, in a successful appeal to Circuit Court of Appeals; representative Russians in property and personal suits when newspaper propaganda had inflamed public opinion; contributed Services to Russian Famine Relief and to Russian-American Industrial Corporation, also to representatives of Soviet Russia in negotiations with Detroit mfrs.; Organizer/Organized/Organization and representative cooperatives; assisted in organization of Ethical Society in Detroit, 1919. Member Masons; Detroit Bar Association; Michigan Bar Association; University of Michigan Club

CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Indicted without evidence on prosecuting attorney's request, with Thomas J. Mooney, Warren K. Billings, and Israel Weinberg, on charge of murdering 10 persons by throwing a bomb into the Preparedness Day parade, San Francisco, July 22, 1916. Spent 9 months in jail and 2 years under bail; police and district attorney then confessed they had no evidence against him; 5 indictments still pending, including charge of constructing bomb in San Francisco at a time when he was in Baltimore as Delegate from lodge 68 to National Convention of International Association of Machinists. Delegate to Los Angeles Labor Council 1904, '10-2; to San Francisco Labor Council 1913-4; San Francisco Iron Trades Council, 1914; captain of pickets in Los Angeles Metal Trades strike 1910

Name: Kate Richards O'hare
TITLES: Lec-turer, author, teacher; dean of women. Commonwealth Coll. since 1923; ed. The American Vanguard since 1920; field dir. of campaign against contract convict labor since 1923.
ORGS: Socialist Party,Commonwealth college,The national rip-saw,The American Vanguard,Field Director of campaign against contract convict labor,Socialist Labor Party,Children's Crusade for Amnesty for Political Prisoners
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): District School, Ottawa County, Kansas; grammar School, Minneapolis, Kansas; High School, Burchard, Nebraska; International School of Social Economy. Formerly School teacher, social worker, housewife. Joined Society Labor Party 1899; transferred to Socialist Party 1900; perhaps covered more territory and delivered more Socialist lectures than any other person in the country; has worked in every state, Canada, Mexico, and Gt. Britain; active in women's suffrage movement, 1900-16; national woman's Committee Socialist Party 1910-2; associate editor The National Rip-Saw, 1911-7; international Secretary of Socialist Party 1912-4, only woman in any country to hold that position in 2nd International; national executive Committee Socialist Party 1912-6; chair, of Committee which wrote Socialist War Manifesto, Apr. 1917; led Children's Crusade for Amnesty for Political Prisoners to Washington 1922; with William Edward Zeuch and Frank Party O'Hare founded Commonwealth College 1923. One of 1st persons convicted under espionage law, sentenced to 5 years In prison; served 14 months in Missouri State Penitentiary at Jefferson City; sentence commuted by Woodrow Wilson on the presentation of proof gathered by the Church Federation of Chicago that the charge was a frame-up, and that language charged in indictment had never been uttered; has spent larger part of time since release working for amnesty for political prisoners, prison reform and elimination of present system of utilizing convict labor, by writing and lecturing on criminology and penology. Married Frank Party O'Hare in 1902; has four children. Author: What Happened to Dan, 1904; Sorrows of Cupid, 1910; Church and Social Problems, 1911; Commonsense and the Liquor Traffic. 1911; Law and the White Slave, 1911; World Peace, 1914; Dear Sweethearts, (letters written from prison to family) 1919; In Prison, 1923. Member Teachers' U

Name: Edgar Owens
TITLES: Org. Work-ers' P., dist. 7, Mich. and Ind., since 1922.
ORGS: Socialist Party,Labor Party,Communist Party,National Defense Committee,Union of Auto Aircraft and Vehicle Workers of America
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Public, High School, Moline. Formerly a carriage and auto worker. Organizer/Organized/Organization in Illinois for Socialist Party until party split in 1919; district secretary Communist Labor Party for Mississippi Valley States 1919-20. Arrested in Red raids, Jan. 1920, at Moline; tried in Communist Labor Party case in Chicago, May 1920; found guilty with other defendants and was among those sentenced to penitentiary; in spite of appeals went to prison Nov. 21, 1922; all pardoned by Governor Small, Nov. 29, 1922. Name: Thomas Morton Pierson
TITLES: Vice-pres. O. of R. R. Telegraph-ers since 1893; natl. legis. rep. since July 1924; ed. staff of Labor since Aug. 1924.
ORGS: Masons,Independent Republican
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Common School education; attended School at Coatesville in winter, worked on farm in summer. Went to work at age of 16. Telegraph operator, 1880; Manager joint general relay telegraph office, E. St. Louis, 1883; train dispatcher Vandalia Railroad, Terre Haute, 1891. Acquainted with Eugene V. Debs. Charter member, Order of Railroad Telegraphers, 1886; and last of original officers., General chair. Vandalia Railroad sect. 1891; secured 1st agreement on rules and wages, 1892. Participated in many struggles for recognition of organization; Canadian Pacific Telegraphers' strike, 1896; Southern Railway strike 1899; Santa Fe Railway strike 1899; in Debs' strike 1894, opposed amalgamation of railroad unions. Member Masons. Independent Republican; assisted in election of Senator Brookhart, Iowa. 1922; spoke in Wisconsin 1922, for progressives; managed campaign for reelection of Congressman John J. Casey, in 12th Congressional District, Pennsylvania, 1924

ORGS: Daily Herald and Daily Citizen,Society of Architects,Salmagundi Club,Independent Labor Party,Brotherhood of Painters
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): University of Budapest 1 yr.; art School, Budapest, for a short time; studied in Munich and Paris. In London, 1907-14; was member Independent Labor Party; helped organize British Agricultural Laborers, 1913; with Keir Hardie assisted in establishment of Daily Herald and Daily Citizen; made cartoons and covers for labor papers and magazines, posters for labor, suffrage and peace movements; one of suffrage posters ordered removed from display by British government Came to United States 1914; decorated Debs Auditorium, People's House, New York; illustrated more than 70 books; directed pageants at Camp Tamiment; is a stage decorator, costume designer, mural painter. Received gold medals in Budapest, Leipzig, Panama Pacific Exposition 1916; silver medal, New York Society of Architects. Member Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators, & Paperhangers of America since 1922; National Arts Club; Salmagundi Club; president The Nest

Name: Felix Pogliano
TITLES: Secy.-treas. dist. 15, United Mine Workers of America, since 1920.
ORGS: United Mine Workers of America,American Legion
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Went to Italy 1890; came to United States 1894. Primary School in coal camps, Fremont County, Colorado, commercial course, night School Started to work in coal mines as trapper boy when 11 years old. Member United Mine W. since age of 12. United States Army 1917-9; served overseas 11 months Arrested during coal strike, 1913-4, just after Ludlow disaster; acquitted with 6 others after 7 weeks' trial. Canon City, Colorado Secretary local union 1903-13; Organizer/Organized/Organization district 15, 1917, 1919-20. Member Knights of Columbus, Foresters, American Legion. Independent Democrat
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Went to Italy 1890; came to U. S. 1894. Prim. sch. in coal camps, Fre-mont County, Colo., commercial course, night sch. Started to work in coal mines as trapper boy when 11 yrs. old. Member Un. Mine W. since age of 12. U. S. Army 1917-9; served overseas 11 mos. Arrested duing coal strike, 1913-4, just after Ludiow dis-aster; acquitted with 6 others af-ter 7 weeks' trial. Canon City, Colo. Secy. loc. u. 1903-13; org. dist. 15, 1917, 1919-20. FREE TEXT: #POGLIANO, Felix. Secy.- treas. dist. 15, Un. Mine W. of A., since 1920. Born July 31, 1888, Colonia Carolina, Argentina. Fa- ther a miller and miner. Went to Italy 1890; came to U.
