Name: Sol Polakoff
TITLES: Bus. mgr. Baltimore jt. bd. of Cloak & Skirt Mkrs.' U., Intl. Ladies' Garment W. U. since 1924.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): At age of 14 ran away from home to Nikolaief, 1500 miles; became tailor's apprentice; after several years started on tour through southern Ukraine; worked in different shops until 1895, when compelled by military duty to return to native town; organized strike in large shop, arrested, paroled on father's guarantee, drafted into army. Went to England, 1895, joined Mantle-makers' Union; executive board, secretary, joined Anarchist group. Came to United States 1897. Joined United Brotherhood of Cloakmakers; was secretary, president, Delegate joint board of Cloakmakers until 1910. Active in many shop strikes until blacklisted and compelled to search for work as far as San Francisco. Took part in l87 organizing International Ladies' Garment W. Union, 1899; Delegate 2nd Convention, and on to 1914; vice president 1906-14; 1st vice president 2 years Sympathized with L W. W.; later fought dual unions; through fight membership of local 9 of Cloakmakers was reduced to mere handful, known as Local Polakoft, 1907-9. Became leader of Cloakmakers' Union on condition of calling general strike; strike called July 7, 1910; assisted in framing protocol of peace in women's garment industry, New York, 1910; elected general Manager Conducted 29-weeks strike in Cleveland in cloak-making industry for organization and collective bargaining. Began similar campaign in Chicago, 1912; returned to New York to organize 30,000 women in dress and waist industry; led 2 strikes; left organization 1917. Helped in strike in Philadelphia, Boston, Cincinnati, St. Louis, Toronto, Montreal, Baltimore, San Francisco, Los Angeles; called general strike Baltimore, July 1924, resulting in unionized shops, creating unemployment insurance for workers, sanitation and fire prevention, and other improvements. Leader of general strike of cloak-makers, Toronto, Canada, 1925. Socialist

CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Elementary, High School, Ireland and England. Organizer/Organized/Organization Industrial Workers of the World 1912-3; Socialist Party for Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, and New York. 1910-1, 1914; editor Buffalo New Age, 1921-3. Visited northern and cent. Europe and Russia, 1919-21. Active in 3 dock strikes and strikes of machinists, hotel and restaurant workers, teamsters, grocery clerks, textile workers; arrested several times. Served 2 years in New Jersey state prison for participation in Industrial Workers of the World textile strike, Paterson. Instrumental in appointment of Commission to investigate prison conditions, New Jersey, which achieved some reforms, among them abolition of prison contract labor; assisted in drafting labor legislation, New York.; assisted in prison reform conferences Socialist

Name: Jackson Harvey Ralston
TITLES: Retired lawyer, writer.
ORGS: International Typographical Union,Columbia Typographical Union,Masons,Cosmos Club,Democratic Party
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): High School, San Francisco; Bachelor of Laws, Georgetown University Law School, 1876. Formerly a compositor; commenced practice of law in Quincy, Illinois, 1878; Delegate International Typographical Union to Europe, 1878. In Washington, District of Columbia, 1881-1924; successfully defended Samuel Gompers, John Mitchell, and Frank Morrison in Bucks Stove & Range proceedings before United States Supreme Court; prevailed in Callan v. Wilson in Supreme Court, involving jury trial in conspiracy cases; argued successfully in Michaelson v. Union S., involving constitutionality of Clayton Act granting jury trial in contempt cases. American Agent Pious Fund case at The Hague in 1902; umpire at Caracas, Venezuela, of Italian-Venezuelan Mixed Claims Commission 1903; counsel IT. 8. in Landreau case, United States v. Peru at London, 1922. President Hyattsville board of commissioners when 1st attempt was made in United States to establish single tax for municipal purposes. Author: Venezuelan Arbitrations of 1903; International Arbitral Law and Procedure 1910; Democracy's International Law 1922; drafter Federal Employers' Liability Act, which was held constitutional; prepared report to American Federation of Labor on Judicial Review of Legislative Acts, 1919; revised and enlarged edition, 1924; prepared in part Maryland constitutional provision securing state wide and local referendum. Honorary member Columbia Typographical Union 101; member Masons; Cosmos Club, Washington, District of Columbia Democrat

Name: Boardman Robinson
TITLES: Cartoonist, instr. Art Students' Lg., New York, since 1919.
ORGS: Painters' and Gravers of America,Players' Club
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Came to United States 1894. Went to work at age of 17 as elevator boy. Public School, Canada and England; Massachusetts Normal Art School; Academic Colorossi and Ecole des Beaux Arts, Paris. After painting 6 years in Paris and San Francisco, located in New York, illustrated for magazines and newspapers; staff New York Tribune, 1910-4; Metropolitan Magazine, 1914-7; New York Call, 1917-23; The Masses; The Liberator. Went to the Balkans and Russia to make drawings, 1915. Author, with John Reed: The War in Eastern Europe, 1916; cartoons of the war, publisher 1915. Member Painters' & Gravers of America, Players' Club
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Came to U. S. 1894. Went to work at age of 17 as elevator boy. Pub. sch., Canada and England; Mass. Normal Art Sch.; Aca-demic Colorossi and Ecole des Beaux Arts, Paris. Name: John Augustine Ryan
TITLES: Clergy-man; prof, moral theology and industrial ethics. Catholic Univ., Washington, D. C., since 1915; dir. Social Action dept. of Natl. Catholic Welfare Conf. since 1920.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): District School; Christian Brothers' School, St. Paul; 1886-7; St. Thomas College 1887-94; St. Paul Seminary 1894-8; postgrad, student, Catholic University 1898-1902; 0. D., 1906. Prof, moral theology and economics, St. Paul Seminary, 1902- 15; founder and for some years editor The Catholic Charities Review; pioneer advocate of minimum wage legislation in Union S.; drafter of Minnesota law on that subject; lecturer on industrial and labor subjects and frequent contributor to periodicals in those fields; most active and authoritative exponent in United States of Catholic social teaching; regarded by many as radical, but admitting himself to be radical only in the sense of going to the roots of social conditions and forces and standing upon the traditional foundation of Catholic social philosophy. Author: A Living Wage, 1906; Alleged Socialism of the Church Fathers, 1913; Socialism: Promise or Menace, (debate with Morris Hillquit), 1914; Distributive Justice, 1916; Social Reconstruction, 1919; The Church and Socialism and other Essays, 1919; The Church and Labor, 1920; The State and the Church, 1922. Prominent in American Association for Labor Legislation, National Consumers' League, National Council for Prevention of War
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Dist. sch.; Christian Brothers' sch., St. Paul; 1886-7; St. Thomas Coll. 1887-94; St. Paul Sem. 1894-8; postgrad, student, Catholic Univ. 1898-1902; 0. D., 1906. S. of Catholic social teaching; regarded by many as radical, but admitting himself to be radical only in the sense of going to the roots of social con- ditions and forces and standing upon the traditional foundation of Catholic social philosophy. Name: James Harvey Ryckman
TITLES: Lawyer.
ORGS: Severance Club of Los Angeles
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Self-educated. Instructor in normal School, Indiana, 1880; high school teacher at Cheyenne, Wyo., 1885-6; practiced law at Evanston, Wyo., and Salt Lake City, Utah, until 1910; since at Los Angeles. Law practice has been in labor cases in all courts, including Federal in Wyoming, Utah, California Writer for labor press on constitutional law and industrial problems, free-lance contributor to Tomorrow, publisher at Los Angeles, and Labor Age, New York. Severed all connections with clubs during world war, except Severance Club of Los Angeles

Name: Nicola. Sacco
TITLES: In Dedham, Mass., prison, awaiting new trial on charges of murder and payroll robbery at South Braintree. Mass., Apr. 15, 1920.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Came to United States 1908. Began work in United States for $1.15 a day, saved enough to become edge-trimmer apprentice in shoe factory where he was guard at night; worked there at intervals 7 years Active in advancing conditions of workers, aided in strikes. Arrested at Brockton, Massachusetts, May 5, 1920, with Bartolomeo Vanzetti, on charge of murder of a paymaster and a guard and theft of $15,000 payroll, at South Braintree. Convicted of 1st degree murder, July 14, 1921. Five motions for new trial filed, on the basis of perjured testimony; 1st motion denied Oct. 1921, other 4 Oct. 1, 1924, by Judge Webster Thayer, who tried the case. in Norfolk Superior Court Fight for freedom to be carried to Massachusetts Supreme Court by radicals and fellow-countrymen who believe justice has miscarried through prejudice against the defendants' avowed radical beliefs. If trial dented again, to be carried to Supreme Court of United States on constitutional questions. Cost of prosecution to Norfolk County was $35,883.16 up to Nov. 14, 1923; defense paid from voluntary subscriptions. When Sacco was first committed to prison, went on hunger strike 31 days, was judged insane and sent to Bridgewater Hospital for Insane, where outdoor work restored health

Name: Freeman M Saltus
TITLES: Printer and publ., ed. and proprietor The Labor News, since 1906, and New England Journal of Labor since 1920; dir. Worcester Cent. Labor Credit U., since 1916; del. since 1904, and fin. rec., and corr. secy, since 1922, Worcester Cent. Labor U.
ORGS: Worcester Central Labor Union,Knights of Labor,Typographical Union,Typographical Union,Central Labor Union,Typographical Union,Central Labor Union,International Typographical Union,American Federation of Labor,International Labor Press of America,Union Labor Temple Associates,Women's Trade Union League,Central Labor Union,Elks,Foresters,Orioles,Artisans,L'Union Saint Jean Baptiste,Knights of Columbus,Leicester Country Club,Bancroft Auto Club,League of Nations Non-Partisan Association,Democratic Party,Worcester Central Labor Credit Union
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Parochial school; Business College 1 term. Went to work at 11 years of age in Department store; 3 years in lumber business; learned printer's trade, asst. foreman of Burlington Free Press at 20 years; grocer; insurance and real estate salesman; letter carrier 3 years; shipping clerk; travelling salesman lord books and library supplies. Active in labor movement since 1886, with Knights of Labor; Secretary and charter member Typographical V., Burlington, 1898; vice president, Springfield, Massachusetts, Typographical Union, and Delegate Cent . Labor Union, 1900-3; president Worcester Typographical Union 1904-6, Delegate to Central Labor Union since 1904; now financial, recording and Correspondence secretary Worcester Central Labor Union Delegate International Typographical Union Convention, Toronto, 1905; Delegate of Worcester Central Labor Union to Philadelphia convention of American Federation of Labor, 1914; vice president International Labor Press of America, 1913-5; president United Labor Temple Associates, 1919-22; active in Liberty Loan drives during war. CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Public School, 6th grade, New York. Helped organize branch of United Cloth Hat & Cap Makers of North America, 1903; served as Secretary-Treasurer; member. executive board and volunteer Organizer/Organized/Organization during noon and evening hours for union while employed in factory 10 hours during day; served on national executive board; Delegate to Conventions; Active in open-shop fight of 1905; joined Women's Trade Union League  1905; vice president 1906; became ; part-time Organizer/Organized/Organization 1908; took part in strike of 30,000 shirt waist-makers, speaking and collecting funds for strikers, 1909-10; became full-time Organizer/Organized/Organization for Women's Trade Union League 1910, organization activities largely in needle trades; in charge  of general strike of White Goods W. Union 1913. General Organizer/Organized/Organization International Ladies' Garment W. Union 1914-6. Returned to Women's Trade Union League as org-. and president 1917. Chairman New York Industrial Department of Woman Suffrage Party campaign, 1917. Was sent by National Women's Trade Union League with Mary Anderson, chief of Women's Bureau of Department of Labor of Mission to Peace Conference at Paris, to present recommendations of American working women, 1919; Delegate to International Cong, of Working Women, Washington, and Vienna, 1919-23. vice president National Women's Trade Union League 1919; served on Committee of cent, bodies which organized Labor Party of New York, 1920. Delegate to national Convention of Famer-Labor Party and member national Committee; candidate for United States Senate on Famer-Labor Party ticket, 1920. Home. 41 Elliott Place: office, 247 Lexington Ave., New York, New York

Name: Frederick Adolph Schwarting
TITLES: Painter; notary public.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Primary, grammar School, Hoboken, self-educated in economics and law. As a boy started to learn nickel plating trade, gave it up as unhealthy; started printing trade, but pay was too low; active in politics since age of 19. In labor movement since age of 21, when became charter member local 372, Marine Painters; financial secretary 4% years; Delegate district Council 7, 4V4 years; Delegate Marine Trades Council of Port of New York, 1 yr.; president, vice president, recording Secretary of district Council 7, 2 years Organizer/Organized/Organization Socialist Party, Hoboken, 3 years; executive secretary Hudson County local 3 years; state Committee and executive Committee Socialist Party, New Jersey, 12 years; state executive secretary 2 years; trustee, president and vice president Socialist Educational Club of Hudson County, 12 years; associate editor and treasurer Hudson County Socialist 3 years; chair. Hudson County McNamara Defense Committee 4 months; national control Committee Workingmen's Sick & Death Benefit Fund 2 years Drafted in World War, served 7 months, including service in France. Nominated for public office many times, once for recorder; assisted strikes, almost branded as arch traitor and seditionist in court, Dec. 1920. Author newspaper articles. Member Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators & Paperhangers of America

Name: Silas Downer Scudder
TITLES: Banker; dir. Labor Coop. Natl. Bank of Paterson, N. J., since or-ganization, 1924.
FATHER: an Amer. medical missionary to In-dia.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Taught by mother up to 12 years; Hastings, England 1 yr.; Kornthal College; Stuttgart, Germany, 5 years Clerk Bank of Montreal, New York., 1879-84; member banking firm, Dyckman & Scudder, Sleepy Eye, Minnesota 1884-7; mortgage banker at San Antonio, Texas, and Agent for Scottish-American Mortgage Company of Edinburgh, Scotland, 1888-95; southern Manager, Germania Fire Insurance Company of New York., 1896-1901; treasurer Trust Company of America, New York, 1902-11; vice president and director Richmond Trust Company, Virginia, 1912-3; special receiver for failed banks, United States Treasury Department, Washington, District of Columbia, 1913-6; vice president and treasurer City Trust Company of Passaic, New Jersey, and vice president Security Mortgage Company of Passaic, 1916-23; vice president Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers' Cooperative National Bank, Cleveland, Ohio, 1923; vice president Locomotive Engineers' Bank, New York, 1924; active in organizing labor banks. Resigned as operating vice president Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers' Cooperative Trust Company of New York., Dec. 1924, to work with union labor to establish labor banks. Politics independent, for La Follette and Wheeler in 1924. Member Masons, Knights Templar, Shriners, Knights of Pythias, Elks

Name: Emil Seidel

On farm since 1924

Name: Maynard Shipley
TITLES: Pres. and gen. org. Science Lg. of A., since founding by him in Aug. 1924, to fight Fundamentalism and all t implies; writer, lecturer.
ORGS: Science League of America,Socialist Party,Seattle Academy of Sciences,Astronomical Society of the Pacific
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Primary School, Baltimore; Leland Stanford University 1901-2; almost entirely self-educated. Was a farm worker, shoe clerk, music teacher. Active as lecturer on evolution for 18 years, largely before working-class organizations and labor colleges; founded Seattle Academy of Sciences 1898; was its 2nd president Editor The World, Oakland, California, 1908-10, '19-20; editor The Northwest Worker 1913-6 and The Labor Journal, Everett, Washington, 1915-6; associated campaign Manager for Eugene V. Debs, 1916; editor Public Ownership, Baltimore, Maryland, 1917-8; all except The Labor Journal, official organ of the Everett Central Trades Council, were Socialist Party papers. Delegate St. Louis Convention, Socialist Party 1917; member Committee which drafted antiwar and antimilitarism resolution; candidate Congress Alameda County, California, 1920. Toured United States for Political Prisoners' Defense Fund, 1918. Author: 18 scientific articles in Haldemann-Julius Little Blue Book Series; also numerous scientific articles in various periodicals, and over 30 articles in legal and criminological reviews on the history of the death penalty; is preparing scientific works for 2 publishers, besides a history of the death penalty in all times and places. Former honorary member Electrical W. Union Member Astronomical Society of the Pacific. No political affiliations at present

Name: Morris Sigman
TITLES: Pres. Intl. Ladies' Garment W. U. since 1923.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Went to England at age of 21; worked in men's clothing shop 1 yr.; came to New York 1903; presser in a cloak shop. Within a yr. Organizer/Organized/Organization independent cloak-makers' union which joined Socialist Trade & Labor Alliance 1904. Organizer/Organized/Organization local 59, Industrial Workers of the World, 1905. Organizer/Organized/Organization New York joint board of Cloakmakers' Union, International Ladies' Garment W., 1908. Active in strike 1910, chair, of picket Committee, member joint conference which worked out protocol agreement signed Sept. 2, 1910. Manager New York joint board, vice president International Ladies' Garment W. Union 1910-3; Manager local 35; introduced system of benefits and financial organization 1913; general Secretary-Treasurer International Union, 1914. Indicted and arrested and committed to Tombs, New York, in connection with strike, 1914; released as not guilty, 1915; resigned as secretary 1915; Manager New York joint board of Cloak-makers' Union 1917; active in carrying through policy of week work in cloak trade 1921; 1st vice president International Union 1920-2; retired from union activities 1922; lived on farm in Iowa until 1923, when elected president after resignation of Benjamin Schlesinger
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Went to Eng-land at age of 21; worked in men's clothing shop 1 yr.; came to New York 1903; presser in a cloak shop. Within a yr. org. independent cloakmakers' union which joined Socialist Trade & Labor All. 1904. Org. loc. 59, I. W. W., 1905. Org. New York jt. bd. of Cloakmkrs.' U., Intl. Ladies' Garment W., 1908. Active in strike 1910, chair, of picket comt., mem-ber jt. conf. which worked out protocol agreement signed Sept. 2, 1910. Mgr. New York jt. bd., vice-pres. Intl. Ladies' Garment W. U. 1910-3; mgr. loc. 35; intro-duced system of benefits and financial organization 1913; gen. secy.-treas. Intl. U., 1914. Indicted and arrested and committed to Tombs, New York, in connection with strike, 1914; released as not guilty, 1915; resigned as secy. 1915; mgr. New York jt. bd. of Cloakmakrs.' U. 1917; active in carrying through policy of week work in cloak trade 1921; 1st vice-pres. Intl. U. 1920-2; retired from union activities 1922; lived on farm in Iowa until 1923, when elected pres. after resignation of Benjamin Schlesinger.
WORK ADDRESS: 3 W. 16 St., New York, New York.

Name: Max Julius Sillins (sillinsky)
TITLES: Secy. Cleveland loc. Jn. Tailors' U. of A., since 1917.
ORGS: Journeymen Tailors' Union of America
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Public School, Vilna; High School, Kovna; Toynbee Hall (labor college), England. Formerly a tailor; Organizer/Organized/Organization for Journeymen Tailors 6 years; chair, of Tailors' Union, London, Eng., 1905-8; led big strike of tailors, 1907. Secretary New York Custom Tailors' local 162, 1910-1; Organizer/Organized/Organization Journeymen Tailors' Union, 1911-6; instrumental in uniting Journeymen Tailors and Amalgamated Clothing W. 1914; amalgamation lasted 1 yr. As Delegate to American Federation of Labor Convention, held out for all progressive measures and introduced resolutions for amalgamation, Russian recognition; presented resolutions to Conventions of Journeymen Tailors' Union of America, which abolished piece work system in favor of week work; led several strikes successfully; editor Jewish Custom Tailor, 6 months President Cleveland Famer-Labor Party 1919-21; candidate Congress 1920; vice president and chair, organizing Committee Cleveland Federation of Labor several terms. Public speaker on labor issues for last 20 years Author: What Every Man Should Know, and other pamphlets on custom tailoring
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Pub. sch., Vilna; high sch., Kovna; Toynbee Hall (labor coll.), Eng-land. Formerly a tailor; org. for Jn. Tailors 6 yrs.; chair, of Tail-ors' U., London, Eng., 1905-8; led big strike of tailors, 1907. Secy. New York Custom Tailors' loc. 162, 1910-1; org. Jn. Tail-ors' U., 1911-6; instrumental in uniting Jn. Tailors and Amal. Clothing W. 1914; amalgamation lasted 1 yr. As del. to A. F. of L. conv., held out for all progres-sive measures and introduced res-olutions for amalgamation, Russian recognition; presented reso-lutions to convs. of Jn. Tailors' U. of A., which abolished piece work system in favor of week work; led several strikes success-fully; ed. Jewish Custom Tailor, 6 mos. Pres. Cleveland Farmer-Labor P. 1919-21; cand. FREE TEXT: #SILLINS (SILLINSKY), Max Julius. Secy. Cleveland loc. Jn. Tailors' U. of A., since 1917. Born Aug. 20, 1883, Podherezia, Viina, Russia. Father a merchant. Pub. sch., Viina; high sch., Kovna; Toynbee Hall (labor coll.), Eng- land. Formerly a tailor; org. for Jn. Tailors 6 yrs.; chair, of Tail- ors' U., London, Eng., 1905-8; led big strike of tailors, 1907. Secy. New York Custom Tailors' loc. 162, 1910-1; org. Jn. Tail- ors' U., 1911-6; instrumental in uniting Jn. Tailors and Amal. Clothing W. 1914; amalgamation lasted 1 yr. As del. to A. F. of L. conv., held out for all progres- sive measures and introduced res- olutions for amalgamation, Rus- sian recognition; presented reso- lutions to convs. of Jn. Tailors' U. of A., which abolished piece work system in favor of week work; led several strikes success- fully; ed. Jewish Custom Tailor, 6 mos. Pres. Cleveland Farmer- Labor P. 1919-21; cand. Cong. 1920; vice-pres. and chair, or- ganizing comt. Cleveland Fed. of Labor several terms. Pub. speak- er on labor issues for last 20 yrs. Author: What Every Man Should Know, and other pamphlets on custom tailoring. Home, 489 E. 127 St.; office 2536 Euclid Ave., Cleveland, Ohio. (214)214 AMERlCAN LABOR WHO'S WHO

Author: Songs of Labor, transl. from Morris Rosenfeld, 1914; The Woman Who Wouldn't, 3-act play, 1917; In April, Saving of Martin Greer, and On the Day, 1-act plays; much uncollected matter in dally press and in magazines on work- ing class topics. Member Clgar- mkrs.' U. 13, retiring card; Pub. Service W. U.; Trade U. Educ. Lg.; Poetry Soc. of A.; Women's Trade U. Lg.; Civic Club; Work- ers' P.; formerly Socialist, 1906- 19. Home, 88 Grove St., New York, N. Y.

Name: George H Strobell
TITLES: Vice-pres. Russian Reconstruction Farms, Inc., since 1924.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Came to United States 1858. Father  served in Civil War and secured citizenship reward.  Left school, Mamaroneck, New York., at age of 11 to work at hat making; learned jeweler's trade; jewelry manufacturer 1880-1916. Joined Governor St. John's Prohibition Party campaign 1884; lecturer, writer, county and state chairman until 1896; member state executive Committee Anti-Saloon League, New Jersey, 1896-1919. One of founders of Direct Legislation League, 1893, was executive secretary and editor The Direct Legislation Record. Joined Socialist Party 1896; attended many conventions; was member and chair, state executive Committee; with Weeks and Ghent organized Collectivist Society 1902; organized, with Upton Sinclair, Intercollegiate Socialist Society, 1903-4, and was executive secretary 2 years; carried on Socialist Forum in 3rd Presbyterian Church, Newark, New Jersey and was elder of church. Was active member New Jersey Men's League for Women's Suffrage. Manager People's House, 7 E. 15 St., New York, 1916-22. Published Italian Socialist paper, Newark, 1908-10. Author: A Christian View of Socialism
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Came to U. S. 1858. Father  served in Civil War and secured citizenship reward. St. John's Prohibition P. campaign 1884; lecturer, writer, county and state chairman until 1896; member state exec. comt. Anti-Saloon Lg., N. J., 1896-1919. One of founders of Direct Legis-lation Lg., 1893, was exec. secy. and ed. The Direct Legislation Record. Name: John Henry Sylvester
TITLES: Sr. vice-grand-pres. Bro. of Ry. & Steamship Clerks, Freight H., E. & S. E. since 1922; vice-grand-presi western dist. 1919-22; ry. clerk.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Grammar School, Pasco, Washington Began tending switch lights at age of 16; worked in ice house; extra gang laborer; cable man on work train; pitman, steam shovel watchman, fireman on steam shovel; work train brakeman; proprietor of railroad eating house 1902; call boy and yard clerk 1903-8; cigar and tobacco business 1909-14; president Sylvester Realty Company, Pasco, 1912-5. Justice of Peace, Pasco, 4 years; twice mayor of Pasco on organized labor ticket, 1912-3; secured passage of minimum wage ordinance on all public work, and repeal of $3 poll tax on workers; labor candidate for state senator, indorsed by Washington Federation of Labor, 1912; defeated in state by small majority but carried home county; deputy county assessor in 1914. Railroad yard clerk 1917-7. President Pasco Central Labor Council 1917; asst. car distributor North. Pac. Railway; general clerk in superintendent's office 1918-9; senior vice general chair, North. Pac. System Board of Adjustment, 1917-9; assigned to represent Brotherhood of Railway Clerks be-chaiman UNCLEAR grand division 3, 1923-4. Joined fore United States Railroad Labor Board 1922; Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, Pasco lodge 372, 1st lodge in west, 1916; chairman during period of organization. Author: articles Doings of Labor Board in Railway Clerk. Member Elks, Knights of Pythias, Moose. Republican; for La Follette-Wheeler, 1924

CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Primary, grammar, high school, Italy. Came to Union S., 1904. Secretary Italian Federation of Railroad W., 1898-1902; secretary Italian Socialist Federation of North America 1904-7; editor 11 Germe, Socialist weekly, Abruzzi, Italy; editor 11 Proletario, 1904-7; editor La Plebe, 1907-9; editor L'Avvenire, 1909-17, suppressed under espionage Action Unofficially took part in Westmoreland, Pennsylvania, strike of United Mine Workers of America, 1908; Lawrence, Massachusetts, textile strike, 1912; hotel workers' general strike, New York, 1912; Little Falls textile strike, 1912; Paterson, New Jersey, textile strike, 1912-3; Calumet Copper Miners' strike, 1912; Iron Range, Minnesota, general strike, 1916; arrested many times during Paterson strike; tried for treason and acquitted; arrested during New York hotel workers strike; tried for disorderly conduct and acquitted; arrested many times in Minnesota, imprisoned for 9 months, charged murder 1st degree, released without trial; arrested in Industrial Workers of the World espionage case, 1917, released; arrested Aug. 1923, on charge of printing advertisement of birth control pamphlet; tried Oct. 1923, found guilty, sentenced to Atlanta for 1 yr. and 1 day; sentence confirmed Nov. 10, 1924; entered penitentiary Jan. 5, 1925. Author: several pamphlets, including Cosa e la Religione; Chi Siamo e Cosa Vogliamo. Member AntiFascisti All

W. National Guard. 8th Regiment, 8 years; active in Pastime Athletic Club 1894-1910, as athlete and captain of track team; afterwards member and official of America A. Union; active in promoting athletic games. Name: Bartolomeo Vanzetti
TITLES: Sen-tenced to prison at Charleston, Mass., for 15 yrs., on charge of attempted payroll robbery at Bridgewater, Mass., Dec. 24, 1919. Awaiting new trial on charges of murder and payroll robbery at South Braintree, Mass., Apr. 15, 1920.
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): School from 6 until 13 years of age. Apprenticed as baker, worked at trade 6 years Came to United States 1908. Worked at dishwashing, brick furnace tending, 10 months, in stone pits 2 years, pastry chef, railroad construction worker, cordage worker 18 months, construction worker for Plymouth; fish peddler. Arrested, with Nicola Sacco, at Brockton, Massachusetts, May 5, 1920, on charge of murder of a paymaster and a guard and theft of $15,000 payroll, at South Braintree. Convicted of 1st degree murder July 14, 1921. Five motions for a new trial were filed on basis of perjured testimony; 1st motion denied Oct. 1921; other 4 denied by Judge Webster Thayer in Norfolk Superior Court, Oct. 1, 1924. Fight for freedom to be carried to Massachusetts Supreme Court by radicals and fellow-countrymen who believe justice has miscarried through prejudice against the defendants' avowed radical beliefs. If denied, may be carried to Supreme Court of United States Sent to Bridgewater Hospital for Insane Jan. 5, 1925. Cost of prosecution to Norfolk County was $35,883.16 up to Nov. 14, 1923. Defense paid from voluntary subscriptions

Five motions for aew trial were filed on basis of perjured testimony; 1st motion denied Oct. 1921; other 4 denied by Judge Webster Thayer in Norfolk Supe-rior Ct., Oct. 1, 1924. If denied, may be carried to Supreme Ct. of U. S. Sent to Bridgewater Hos-pital for Insane Jan. 5, 1925. Cost of prosecution to Norfolk County was $35,883.16 up to Nov. 14, 1923. Defense paid from volun-tary subscriptions.

Lived on farm in Minn. 15 yrs.; worked in shoe factory 1 yr.; with printing co. 2 yrs.; machin- ists' helper 1 yr.; ry. clerk for St. Paul Union depot 5 yrs.; Omaha Ry. 2 yrs.; N. Pac. Ry. 2 yrs. Active in movt. to organize ry. clerks at gen. office of N. Pac. Ry., 1916; movt . failed when co. discharged a number of leaders. Secy. St. Paul city cent. comt. of Socialist P. 1912-7; asst. secy. Minn., 1916-7; held several other positions in party. Ed. The Rail- (241)AMERlCAN LABOR WHO'S WHO 24l road Amalgamation Advocate. Home, 800 Como Blvd.; office, 411 Dakota Bldg., 54 W. 7 St., St. Paul, Minn.

ORGS: International Cooperative Alliance,American Medical Association,American Academy of Medicine,American College of Surgery,Teachers' Union,Civic Club of New York,Cooperative League of United States of America,Brookwood Labor College Associated Physicians of Long Island Brooklyn Pathological Society Brooklyn Surgical Society 10th International Cooperative Congress llth International Cooperative Congress
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Newton, New Jersey High School; Columbia University; University of Gottingen, Germany; University of Vienna, Austria. Fellow: American Medical Association, American Academy of Medicine, American College of Surgery, New York Academy of Medicine. President Associated Physicians of Long Island, Brooklyn Pathological Society, Brooklyn Surgical Society Delegate 10th International Cooperative Congress, Basel, Switzerland, 1921; 11th International Cooperative Congress, Ghent, Belgium. 1924. Author: pamphlets, The Economics of Medicine, Poverty as a Cause of Disease, The Healing Power of Social Justice, The Ethics of Sabotage, The Red Cross and the War, The Effects of War, Military Surgery, and about 100 others on scientific subjects, 1892-1916, and about 25 on cooperation, 1915-24; books, Samuel Johnson and his Court, 1903; Medical Sociology. 1908; The Conquest of Disease, Surgical Treatment in 3 vols. including economics of surgery, 1918; Cooperative Democracy, 1923; Workers' Cooperation, 1924. Travelled and studied cooperation in all United States and Canada, England, Scotland, Wales, France, Belgium. Holland, Denmark, Switzerland, Germany, Czechoslovakia, Austria, Italy, Norway, Sweden, Finland, Latvia, Lithuania, Russia; lectured on cooperation in colleges and universities in Union S., before trade unions and cooperation societies, also at International summer School at Basel, International College at Elsinore, Denmark, and before labor bodies and cooperation societies m Switzerland, Germany, Czechoslovakia and Russia. CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Acquitted on 1 count of charges of murder in San Francisco Preparedness Day parade bomb explosion, July 22, 1916; 8 other indictments still pending. Twice refused $5,000 bribe to testify against Thomas J. Mooney in street car strike, San Francisco, July, 1916, and later refused to accept liberty and $5,000 to perjure away Mooney's life. Had never even met Warren K. Billings and Edward D. Nolan, also held in Mooney case, until introduced to them in jail as fellow conspirators.

Name: Hulet Martell Wells
TITLES: National committee, Labor Defense Council since 1923; builder.
ORGS: Labor Defense Council,Socialist Party,Seattle Labor Council,Red International of Labor Unions,Labor Legal Bureau,Friends of Soviet Russia,Federation of Post Office Clerks,Steam and Operating Engineers
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Grammar School, La Conner; law course, University of Washington, 1905-7. Was a farmer, laborer, gold miner, timber worker, School teacher, Party Order clerk, municipal lighting rate clerk, shipyard worker. Admitted to bar, 1907, but deterred from practice by scruples. Expelled from postal service by Postmaster-General Hitchcock for organizing union, 1908. Editor Seattle Socialist Voice 1911. Socialist candidate for mayor, Seattle, 1912; state chair. Socialist Party of Washington 1913. President Seattle CentralLabor Council 1915-6; fraternal Delegate to Red International of Labor Unions 1921. Member strike Committee Seattle general strike 1919; secretary Labor Legal Bureau 1921. National lecturer Friends of Soviet Russia 1922. Was imprisoned 1.5 years for antiwar opinions. Author: A Wrong Without a Remedy, pamphlet on gag rule in civil service, 1909; The Eight Hour Law, initiative argument used by Washington 8-hour-League in 1914 election; Wilson and Issues of Today, 1918; report on Proceedings of 1st Cong, of Red International of Labor Unions, 1922. Member successively, Federation of Party Order Clerks, Electrical W., Steam & Operating Engineers, Firemen & Oilers
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Gram. sch., La Conner; law course, Univ. of Wash., 1905-7. Was a farmer, laborer, gold miner, timber worker, sch. teacher, P. O. clerk, municipal lighting rate clerk, shipyard worker. Admitted to bar, 1907, but deterred from practice by scruples. Expelled from postal service by Postmaster-Gen. Hitchcock for organizing union, 1908. Ed. Seattle Socialist Voice 1911. Socialist cand. for mayor, Seattle, 1912; state chair. Social-ist P. of Wash. 1913. Pres. Seattle 'ent. CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Private and public school., Oakland; Normal School, San Jose; Bachelor of Science, Wellesley, 1889. CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Public School, New York; Columbia, 1917; special courses College City of New York, 1918. Name: John McClelland Work
TITLES: As-so. ed. Milwaukee Leader since 1917.
ORGS: Socialist Party,Newspaper Writers' Union,American Library Association
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Country School and worked on farm until 1886; Washington Academy, Washington, Iowa, 1889; Bachelor of Arts, Monmouth College, Monmouth, I1l., 1891; Bachelor of Laws, Law School, Columbian (now George Washington) University, Washington, District of Columbia, 1882; special courses. Practiced law, Des Moines, Iowa, 1892-1900. Delegate 1901 Convention at which Socialist Party was born, and to later con vs.; member national executive Committee Socialist Party, 1903-10, 1916-9; national lecturer and Organizer/Organized/Organization, Socialist Party, 1904-10; Socialist candidate for elector-at-large, Iowa, 1900-4; for mayor of Des Moines, 1902; for governor of Iowa, 1903, '10; for United States Senator, 1908; for alderman, Chicago, in spring of 1914; for Cong, in fall of 1914; for judge of superior court, Chicago, 1917; national secretary Socialist Party, 1911-3. Teacher of law, La Salle Extension University, 1913-7. Writer of articles since 1902, many syndicated to Socialist and other labor papers. Author: What's So and What Isn't, 1905; Where You Get Off, 1913; The Key to the Mystery, 1914; Why Things Happen to Happen, 1919; also 6 legal booklets for use of students; wrote 4 or 5 antiwar editorials for which Victor L. Berger was indicted; testified to same at Chicago trial. Member Newspaper Writers' Union; American Library Association; board trustees Milwaukee Public Library
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Country sch. and worked on farm until 1886; Washington Acad., Washington, Iowa, 1889; A.B., Monmouth Coll., Monmouth, I1l., 1891; LL.B., Law Sch., Co-lumbian (now George Washing-ton) Univ., Washington, D. Name: Art (Arthur Henry) Young
TITLES: Cartoonist for The Liberator, Life, The Nation, and other magazines.
ORGS: Socialist Party
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Grammar School, Monroe, Wisconsin Began to work at age of 19 as advertising illustrator for wholesale grocery house, Chicago, and studied at Chicago Art Institute Reporter and cartoonist for Chicago Inter-Ocean, Tribune, Daily News, until 1892. Came to New York 1895; contributor to Life, Colliers, Saturday Evening Post, The Nation, Judge. Studied a short time at New York Art Students' League, and at Julien's, Paris. Helped to start The Masses (later The Liberator) 1910. Indicted for alleged libelous cartoon by Associated Press; case dismissed. Arrested because of Masses' opposition to conscription; jury disagreed and case dropped. Editor Good Morning, 1919. Candidate for New York. State senator, Socialist Party, 1916. Washington Correspondence and cartoonist Metropolitan Magazine, 1912-7. Now member of no political party

Name: Sam Young
TITLES: Rec., fin. secy. Harrisburg br., Socialist P., since 1908; exec. comt. Harrisburg Com-munity Forum since 1922.
ORGS: Red Men,Moose,Socialist Party,Harrisburg Community Forum,Rand School of Social Science,Pennsylvania Federation of Labor,Young People's Socialist League,American Federation of Labor
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Public School, Harrisburg; Northwestern University, 1888-90; Correspondence courses, Rand School of Social Science; study classes Pennsylvania Federation of Labor 1922-4. Went to work at 12 years of age in iron, steel works, brick yards, gardening, grocery store clerk, insurance Agent until 21; in western states 16 years; travelled 10 years; salesman in Pennsylvania, New Jersey (Atlantic City in summers), since 1900. Active in Socialist movement 25 years; paid dues since 1904; financial recording secretary; Organizer/Organized/Organization; literature Agent; Pennsylvania executive Committee many years; secured Debs as speaker in Harrisburg when he was routed by Appeal to Reason; Delegate Pennsylvania Convention, 1908-24; trustee Cooperative store, Secretary of printing company, 1910-2; Organizer/Organized/Organization Young People's Socialist League, president, 1st treasurer, although beyond age limit; elected instructor in Correspondence courses of Rand School of Social Science, by study class; opposed to war, refused to support it in any way. Gets open-air speakers, introduces them; always carries propaganda literature in grip. Author: 20 articles on Red Flag in The Torch, 1910-2; other articles; editorials; Sam Young Says, talks for salesmen. Member Red Men, Moose
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Pub. sch., Harrisburg; Northwestern Univ., 1888-90; corr. courses, Rand Sch. of Social Science; study classes Pa. Fed. of Labor 1922-4. Went to work at 12 yrs. of age in iron, steel works, brick yards, gardening, grocery store clerk, ins. agt. until 21; in west-ern states 16 yrs.; travelled 10 yrs.; salesman in Pa., N. J. (At-lantic City in summers), since 1900. Active in Socialist movt. 25 yrs.; paid dues since 1904; fin. rec. secy.; org.; literature agt.; Pa. exec. comt. many yrs.; se-cured Debs as speaker in Harris-burg when he was routed by Ap-peal to Reason; del. Pa. conv., 1908-24; trustee coop. store, secy, of printing co., 1910-2; org. Young People's Socialist Lg., pres., 1st treas., although beyond age limit; elected instr. in corr. courses of Rand Sch. of Social Science, by study class; opposed to war, re-fused to support it in any way. Gets open-air speakers, introduces them; always carries propaganda literature in grip. Author: 20 ar-ticles on Red Flag in The Torch, 1910-2; other articles; edi-torials; Sam Young Says, talks for salesmen. Member Red Men, Moose.

Name: Philip Zausner
TITLES: Secy. New York. dist. coun., Bro. of Painters, Dec-orators & Paperh. of A., since 1918; bus. agt. since 1916, except 1921, when declined.
ORGS: International Painters' Union,Brotherhood of Painters Decorators and Paperhangers of America
CAREER (UNABBREVIATED): Public, High School, Lemberg. Apprentice 4 years engraving and lettering; journeyman engraver, sign painter in Lemberg 5 years; came to Union S., 1907; house painter. Spokesman for 5,000 members of International Painters' Union, at American Federation of Labor Convention, Atlanta, 1912, for purpose of securing charter with jurisdiction over repair work; conference led to amalgamation with Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators & Paperhangers of America by 1914; active since then in New York district; led several important strikes of New York painters, raised wages from $4 to $10.50 a day, and reduced working week from 5 1-2 to 5 days; helped bring about 1st health agreement in United States for protection of painters against occupational diseases. Active in Socialist and Progressive political labor movements
CAREER (ABBREVIATED): Pub., high sch., Lemberg. Apprentice 4 yrs. engraving and lettering; journeyman engraver, sign paint-er in Lemberg 5 yrs.; came to U. S., 1907; house painter. F. of L. conv., Atlanta, 1912, for purpose of se-curing charter with jurisdiction over repair work; conf. led to amalgamation with Bro. of Paint-ers, Decorators & Paperh. of A. by 1914; active since then in New York dist.; led several important strikes of New York painters, raised wages from $4 to $10.50 a day, and reduced working week from 5 1-2 to 5 days; helped bring about 1st health agreement in U. S. for protection of painters against occupational diseases. Ac-tive in Socialist and Progressive political labor movts.
